ENG100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Practical tools for writing in university and beyond. Students will gain experience in generating ideas, clarifying insights, structuring arguments, composing paragraphs and sentences, critiquing and revising their writing, and communicating effectively to diverse audiences. This course may not be counted toward any English program.

ENV100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An investigation of the relationship between human beings and their natural and built environments. This interdisciplinary course will draw from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
ENV100H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
ENV100H1F will be conducted entirely online. Lectures and tutorials will be conducted asynchronously.
Each noon on the day of the regularly scheduled class (Tuesday and Thursday), the recorded lecture will be made available on Quercus in video format, complete with slides. Students will be asked to send questions between lectures via email, and their questions will be addressed in subsequent lectures. 
Tutorials will be led by TAs, and tutorials will consist of a mixture of online chat rooms, email inquiries, videoed how-to sessions.
Students will be required to submit essay-type assignments via Turnitin.

FSL100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An intensive basic course in spoken and written French for students who have no knowledge of French: comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
FSL100H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: This is a 6-hour course (4-hr lecture, 2-hr tutorial). Students will be assigned a tutorial by the instructor at the beginning of classes. Students with NO previous knowledge of French will enroll in this course and are NOT required to do the online placement test.

PHY100H1-F-20215.courseDescription:
This course provides a survey of Physics, including both Classical and Modern Physics. It is designed for non-scientists, and assumes no background in either science or mathematics. The approach to the course is broad rather than deep. We will concentrate on the concepts underlying such fascinating topics as planetary motion, chaos, the nature of light, time travel, black holes, matter waves, Schrodinger's cat, quarks, and climate change. We will uncover the wonders of the classical and the quantum worlds courtesy of Galileo, Newton, Maxwell, Einstein, Heisenberg and many others.

(PHY100H1 is primarily intended as a Breadth Requirement course for students in the Humanities and Social Science)
PHY100H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an on-line course. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion) will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Tutorials will follow the same principle. Some synchronous attendance may be required, in particular for assessments. Further details will be provided at a later date.

PSY100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include physiological, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
PSY100H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online.  Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.  Opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., virtual office hours) will be made available, but will not be required.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

RSM100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to management and its subdisciplines. Themes include business in a Canadian context, the nature of corporations, corporate governance, organizational behavior, operations, and strategy. Enrolment limited to students entering the University with an expressed interest in studying at Rotman Commerce.
RSM100H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lecture will be held synchronously for two hours each class twice a week.  Lecture will be delivered via Zoom.


Please note that this course is restricted to year 1 students who have not yet been accepted in the Rotman Commerce Program.

SLA100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Basic features of the grammar. Acquisition of essential vocabulary for practical conversation and for comprehension. Development of reading and writing skills. (May not be taken by students who, in the judgment of the Department, qualify for entry into SLA210H1 or SLA220Y1).
SLA100H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This course will be offered through online synchronous meetings. There will be ten hours of online synchronous delivery as per the meeting schedule. 

 

Mon to Fri, 10-12, synchronous.

SOC100H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives
SOC100H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course will challenge your views on a wide range of issues that affect us all. It will also excite your interest in a unique sociological way of understanding your world. We will analyze the globalization of culture, emerging patterns of class, race, and gender inequality in Canada and internationally, criminal and deviant behaviour, and so on. You will learn to understand these and other pressing social issues by analyzing the way the social world is organized. These topics are further taken up in the sequel to this course, SOC150: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries.
SOC100H1-F-20215.exclusion: SOC101Y1, SOC102H1, SOC103H1, SOCA01H3, SOCA02H3; SOC100H5
SOC100H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Quercus, UofT 0365 MS Teams or Skype for Business
SOC100H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone for office hours.

This course will be asynchronous. Lecture videos will be posted on Quercus by the morning of the day on Tuesday and Friday weekly. Tutorials to review key concepts will be recorded and posted by your Teaching Assistants by the end of the day on Tuesday and Friday.

AST101H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Our place in the Universe. Phenomena we see in the sky. What we know about the Sun, the planets and comets, and the formation of the solar system – and how we know it. What makes planets suitable for life. Finding out about the nearest stars and their planets. This course is intended for students with no science or engineering background.
AST101H1-F-20215.exclusion: AST121H1, AST221H1. Also excluded are CIV100H1, CIV101H1, CIV102H1, any 100- or higher-series CHM/PHY courses taken previously or concurrently (with the exception of PHY100H1, PHY101H1, PHY201H1, PHY202H1, PHY205H1, PHY207H1, CHM101H1; and AP, IB, CAPE, and GCE Transfer Credits)
AST101H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online course that involves two weekly lecture sessions (Tuesday and Thursday 6:00 – 8:00 pm EST). The lecture format will rotate between live synchronous lectures, livestreaming of recorded lectures, and asynchronous lectures where lecture time is reserved for a question and answer period. All lectures will be recorded for students wishing to take the course asynchronously. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate via Quercus.

ECO101H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
ECO101H1-F-20215.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)
ECO101H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: WW CHRM Certificate in Human Resources Management students are also eligible to enrol when course enrolment becomes available.
ECO101H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
LEC0101 & 5101: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule, and students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

LEC0201 & 0301: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

GRK101H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An intensive introduction to Ancient Greek for students who have no knowledge of the language; preparation for the reading of Ancient Greek literature.
GRK101H1-F-20215.exclusion: GRK100Y1 Students who have studied Ancient Greek previously must obtain permission from the Undergraduate Coordinator before enrolling.
GRK101H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: An intensive introduction to Ancient Greek for students who have no knowledge of the language; preparation for the reading of Ancient Greek literature.

LAT101H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An intensive introduction to Latin for students who have no knowledge of the language; preparation for the reading of Latin literature.
LAT101H1-F-20215.exclusion: LAT100Y1. Students who have studied Latin previously must obtain permission from the Undergraduate Coordinator before enrolling.
LAT101H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: An intensive introduction to Latin for students who have no knowledge of the language; preparation for the reading of Latin literature.

LIN101H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to fundamental principles of linguistics with particular attention to sound structure and its acquisition, processing, and variation; practice in elementary analytic techniques using data from a broad spectrum of languages.
LIN101H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

FAH102H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
FAH102H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of the lectures will also be made available for students to view asynchronously.

NMC102H1-F-20215.courseDescription: From city state to empire. The peoples and polities of Mesopotamia and the Near East, including Sumerians, Assyrians, Babylonians, and Persians. Their cultural contributions, from the development of writing to their achievements in law, administration, science, art and architecture, religion, and literature.
NMC102H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. Attendance in class via Blackboard Collaborate/Quercus is mandatory. Audio equipment is required; Camera preferred but not required.

ESS103H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Geologic hazards: earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunamis. The distribution and politics of natural resources, including petroleum and ore deposits. Nuclear power and nuclear waste disposal. Global change: the geologic record of hot and cold climates, and how the earth survives. ESS103H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science, it will be taught in odd years.
ESS103H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: There is a required textbook. Do not buy a used textbook. You can contact the instructor for financial assistance with the textbook when the course begins.
ESS103H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. There will be office hours hosted on Blackboard Collaborate to give everyone a chance to ask questions.

ESS105H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The nature and evolution of the Earth; plate tectonics; rocks and minerals; volcanism; geological time; fossils; geology of Ontario; environmental issues; and human interactions with the planet. ESS105H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science students
ESS105H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: There is a required textbook. Do not buy a used textbook. You can contact the instructor for financial assistance with the textbook when the course begins.
ESS105H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. There will be office hours hosted on Blackboard Collaborate to give everyone a chance to ask questions.

GGR107H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Examines the relations between food, nature, and society. Food is fundamental to human existence, and central to most cultures; it also has significant and widespread effects on the physical and social environments. Food is used as a lens to explore human-environment interactions locally and globally. Serves as an introduction to environmental and human geography.

POL107H1-F-20215.courseTitle: What Went Wrong? A Post Mortem of Political Disasters, Catastrophic Policy Failures, and Epic Marches of Folly
POL107H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Why do individuals, groups, and societies make repeated, and often easily predictable mistakes? Why do they persist in courses of action that produce disastrous results? Why is it that in the political world good intentions are insufficient to ensure good results? This course employs the political science analytical toolkit to answer these questions and examines an array avoidable disasters, from the local to the international.
POL107H1-F-20215.exclusion: POL486H1 (Topics in International Politics I: What Went Wrong? A Post Mortem of Political Disasters, Policy Failures and Marches of Folly), offered in Winter 2019 and Winter 2020; POL487H1 (Topics in International Politics II: What Went Wrong? A Post Mortem of Political Disasters, Catastrophic Policy Failures), offered in Winter 2018

BIO120H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Principles and concepts of evolution and ecology related to origins of adaptation and biodiversity. Mechanisms and processes driving biological diversification illustrated from various perspectives using empirical and theoretical approaches. Topics include: genetic diversity, natural selection, speciation, physiological, population, and community ecology, maintenance of species diversity, conservation, species extinction, global environmental change, and invasion biology. A lab coat is required and the cost is approximately $16 if students wish to purchase it through the Department. (Lab Materials Fee: $25)
BIO120H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Grade 12 Biology or equivalent. Students without high school Biology must consult the BIO120 Office (bio120@utoronto.ca)
BIO120H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an online, synchronous course. 
Lectures will be given as two 2 hr online videos a week synchronously. 
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online tutorials with the lecturer each week. 
Labs will run synchronously online Tuesdays (P0101) or Thursdays (P0201) from 1-4 pm. 
Students need to be online during their scheduled lab time. 
For more information, please contact bio120@utoronto.ca
Students will need: regular access to a computer (note that smartphones are not guaranteed to work for all aspects of the course, and a laptop or desktop computer is recommended); an Internet connection and web browser that allows use of Quercus and Bb Collaborate ; Word processing software (if you do not already have this, Office 365 ProPlus can be accessed through U of T).

BIO130H1-F-20215.courseDescription: One of the goals of modern biology is to understand how the basic building blocks of life give rise to biological form and function. This course provides students with a common lexicon to understand the key principles and concepts in molecular and cell biology, with a focus on how the building blocks of life lead to functioning cells. (Lab Materials Fee: $10). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
BIO130H1-F-20215.prerequisite: SBI4U and SCH4U (Grade 12 University Preparation Biology and Chemistry) or permission of department. Please contact bio130@utoronto.ca for more information.
BIO130H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Work associated with labs will begin the second week of class. All labs are on Mondays from 1-4 pm and students need to be available online during this time. You can find out your lab group (e.g., P0101A) by logging into Quercus and looking under the Groups section. The lab manual and all course information will be available on the course website on Quercus. For more information, please contact bio130@utoronto.ca.
BIO130H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Delivery of lectures and practicals will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. The course instructor will provide details on Quercus.

PHY131H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A first university physics course primarily for students not intending to pursue a Specialist or Major program in Physical or Mathematical Sciences. Topics include: classical kinematics & dynamics, momentum, energy, force, friction, work, power, angular momentum, oscillations, waves, sound.
PHY131H1-F-20215.corequisite: MAT135H1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1 recommended, but may be required prerequisite in 2nd year Physics courses
PHY131H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an on-line course. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion) will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Some synchronous attendance may be required during lecture times, in particular for assessments. Synchronous participation is required for the Practicals. Further details will be provided at a later date.

MAT135H1-F-20215.courseDescription: In this first introduction to Calculus, students will be introduced to the tools of differential calculus, the branch of calculus that is motivated by the problem of measuring how quantities change. Students will use these tools to solve other problems, including simplifying functions with straight lines, describing how different types of change are related, and computing maximum and minimum quantities. This course will focus on developing a deep understanding of why the tools of calculus make sense and how to apply them to the social, biological, and physical sciences. It will also emphasize translating between algebraic, graphical, numerical and verbal descriptions of each concept studied.
MAT135H1-F-20215.exclusion: MAT133Y1, MAT136H1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, MATA30H3, MATA31H3, MATA32H3, MATA33H3, MATA35H3, MATA36H3, MATA37H3,  MAT133Y5, MAT134Y5, MAT135Y5, MAT137Y5, MAT138Y5, MAT186H, MAT187H, MAT194H, MAT195H, MAT196H &  MAT197H
MAT135H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

CHM136H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to principles of structure and their relation to reactivity of organic molecules: molecular structure, stereochemistry, functional groups, and reactions. Recommended for students in life and health science programs that involve a small amount of chemistry. (Lab Materials Fee: $25).
CHM136H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Chemistry SCH4U, Mathematics MHF4U + MCV4U, CHM135H1
CHM136H1-F-20215.corequisite: MAT135H1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1 recommended, but may be required prerequisite in 2nd year Chemistry courses;(PHY131H1, PHY132H1)/(PHY151H1, PHY152H1) recommended
CHM136H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an online course that has both synchronous and asynchronous components. Most classes will be given asynchronously 2 x 2 hr. online videos/week, and some will be delivered synchronously through online problem-solving sessions 2 x 1 hr. Students may attend online “office hours” to ask questions and clarifications about class content: the days/times of these hours are to be determined. 


Tutorial content will be posted online weekly, and online synchronous sessions will be offered for discussions, questions and clarifications of the tutorial content (twice x 1 hr./week). 


Weekly virtual laboratory content will be posted online weekly and practical exercises will be run synchronously during regularly-scheduled laboratory hours (1 hr./week): specific times of this hour is to be determined. 
Students require access to Microsoft Office (PowerPoint, Excel, and Word) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom. 


The expectation is that students connect to all course activities using a desktop/laptop computer through a web browser using a stable internet connection (not a cellphone).

MAT136H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This second part of the introductory Calculus sequence focuses on integral calculus beginning with the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, the connection between two seemingly unrelated problems: measuring changing quantities and finding areas of curved shapes. Students will develop a deep understanding of the integral, and use it to: unpack equations involving derivatives; to make sense of infinite sums; to write complicated functions as 'infinite polynomials'; and to compute areas, volumes, and totals in applied problems. This course will further develop students' abilities to translate between algebraic, graphical, numerical, and verbal descriptions of mathematics in a variety of applied contexts.
MAT136H1-F-20215.exclusion: MAT133Y1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1,  MATA32H3, MATA33H3, MATA36H3, MATA37H3,  MAT133Y5, MAT134Y5, MAT135Y5, MAT137Y5, MAT138Y5, MAT186H, MAT187H, MAT194H, MAT195H, MAT196H &  MAT197H
MAT136H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT138H1-F-20215.courseDescription:
The goal of this course is for students to become comfortable with abstraction, rigour, logic, and proofs. They will practice reading and understanding mathematical statements, analyzing definitions and properties, formulating conjectures and generalizations, providing and writing reasonable and precise arguments, writing and critiquing proofs. The instructor may use specific mathematical content, which could vary from year to year, to practice these skills. The course is aimed at students interested in the creative character of mathematics, particularly those planning to take any of our proof-oriented courses, and is an excellent preparation for MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, or MAT240H1.


Note: students may take this course concurrently with MAT157Y1 or MAT137Y1, or prior to registering in MAT157Y1 or MAT137Y1. This course can also be used by students who have already taken MAT136H1 and wish to bridge the gap to MAT237Y1.
MAT138H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

CLA160H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to major themes in the development of Greek and Roman civilization, literature and culture.

CTA200H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Research in theoretical astrophysics encompasses cosmology, galaxy formation and black holes. This course introduces students to modern computational techniques using large scale parallel numerical simulations, carried out at CITA and SciNet. This is an intensive two-week course taught in May.
CTA200H1-F-20215.prerequisite: MAT135Y1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1; (PHY131H1, PHY132H1)/(PHY151H1, PHY152H1) or their equivalent.
CTA200H1-F-20215.recommendedPreparation: Physical science, mathematics and computation, or engineering

DTS200Y1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Diaspora and Transnational Studies I
DTS200Y1-F-20215.courseDescription: What is the relationship between place and belonging, between territory and memory? How have the experiences of migration and dislocation challenged the modern assumption that the nation-state should be the limit of identification? What effect has the emergence of new media of communication had upon the coherence of cultural and political boundaries? All of these questions and many more form part of the subject matter of Diaspora and Transnational Studies. This introductory course ex-amines the historical and contemporary movements of peoples and the complex issues of identity and experience to which these processes give rise as well as the creative possibilities that flow from movement and being moved. The area of study is comparative and interdisciplinary, drawing from the social sciences, history, the arts and humanities. Accordingly, this course provides the background to the subject area from diverse perspectives and introduces students to a range of key debates in the field, with particular attention to questions of history, globalization, cultural production and the creative imagination.
DTS200Y1-F-20215.breadthCategories: Creative and Cultural Representations (1), Society and its Institutions (3)

ENV200H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment
ENV200H1-F-20215.courseDescription:
The perspective which scientists bring to the understanding and resolution of environmental concerns having global implications: atmospheric systems and climate change, the biosphere and conservation of biodiversity.

This living things and their environment breadth course is intended to fulfill the environmental literacy requirement for students in the BA programs of the School of the Environment or the living things and their environment breadth course requirement for Commerce, Humanities and Social Science students
ENV200H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
The lectures, tutorials, assignments and final exam are asynchronous. 
The only component that makes this course synchronous is the mid-term test. You will log on to Quercus during a specific time to take the mid-term test.

HMB200H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introductory course that explores the development, physiology and continually changing function of the nervous system as it relates to certain types of human behaviour. Critical analysis of scientific evidence is used to enrich learning.
HMB200H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an online synchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be fully online via live webinar (using Blackboard Collaborate Ultra – accessed within Quercus) on Tuesdays and Thursdays 10am to 1pm (Eastern Time). 
Lectures and tutorials will be recorded for asynchronous viewing, but it is strongly recommended that all students “attend” online all lectures and tutorials.

INS200H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Indigenous Truth and Resilience
INS200H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course is an interdisciplinary introduction to the historical and contemporary experiences of Indigenous peoples in Canada, with an emphasis on local lands and peoples. The course will explore Indigenous resilience, relationships with settlers and settler states, and principles and ethics of Indigenous Knowledge. Tutorials will focus on critical discussion and experiential learning.

GGR201H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the principles of geomorphology; earth materials; major features of crustal morphology; landforming processes of water, wind, waves and ice; human impact on earth surface processes. One hour laboratory session approximately every other week; a local field trip.
GGR201H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lecture and laboratory webinars will be delivered synchronously during the scheduled time. Students are strongly encouraged to attend laboratory webinars synchronously. Recordings of lectures and laboratories will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone in order to participate in online activities, although this is not required.

JPI201H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course explores key issues in Indigenous politics in Canada. Provides students with an overview of historical and contemporary socio-political issues in Indigenous societies and institutions such as Indigenous self-governance, land claims and treaty negotiations.
JPI201H1-F-20215.prerequisite: 4.0 credits including 1.0 POL credit or INS201Y1
JPI201H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students may watch/listen to lectures and other class material on their own schedule.
  • Students require the use of a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online tutorials.

LAT201H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Reading of selections of Latin prose works with systematic language study.
LAT201H1-F-20215.prerequisite: LAT100Y1/LAT102H1. Grade 12 in Latin may be accepted, but students should consult the Undergraduate Coordinator before enrolling.
LAT201H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Reading of selections of Latin prose works with systematic language study.

POL201H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course offers an introduction to the history and politics of economic and political development, starting with the Industrial Revolution and then turning to a critical analysis of the politics of economic growth, international trade, debt, state intervention, protectionism, and neo-liberalism in the global periphery, including Africa, Asia, and Latin America.
POL201H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedules.
  • All the planned lectures are posted and available on Quercus.
  • Students are encouraged to read required readings before class.
  • Students are required to have a computer with a microphone.
  • Camera is recommended in order to participate in online tutorials and discussion but not mandatory.

PSY201H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics, including population and sampling distributions, simple association, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing.
PSY201H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This will be an online asynchronous course. Lectures will be available asynchronously for students to view at any time. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions and clarifications about class through the Quercus Discussion Board, email, or virtual office hours.

SOC201H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the history, nature, and role of sociological theory, through an examination of the works of key classical theorists such as Karl Marx, Max Weber, Emile Durkheim, Georg Simmel, and others. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
SOC201H1-F-20215.prerequisite: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1

SOC202H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Quantitative Methods in Sociology
SOC202H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction in quantitative social science research from descriptive statistics to hypothesis testing using various strategies for the analysis of bivariate relationships. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
SOC202H1-F-20215.prerequisite: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1
SOC202H1-F-20215.exclusion: SOC200Y5, SOC222H5, ECO220Y1, ECO227Y1, GGR270H1, PSY201H1, STA220H1, STA248H1, POL222H1, POL232H1, POL242Y1, POL322H1, STA288H1
SOC202H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: BB Collaborate (through Quercus) and SPSS (free download); MS Word
SOC202H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone; Lectures and tutorials are synchronous.

Textbook: Healey, Joseph F., Steven G. Prus, and Riva Lieflander. 2019. Statistics: A Tool for Social Research, 4th Canadian Ed. Nelson Education Ltd.

The textbook is available as an e-book or as hard copy, both available at https://www.nelsonbrain.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/en/micrositesca/UofT-SOC202. The ebook comes bundled with MindTap Instant Access, the online platform this class uses for homework assignments ($59.95). The other option, hard copy text package ($131.95), provides the print text and an access code for MindTap. If you choose to purchase a used textbook, you will need to also purchase MindTap Instant Access.

ENG203H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to British literature, exploring works in poetry, prose, and drama from the end of the seventeenth century into the twentieth century.

LIN203H1-F-20215.courseDescription: English has a rich vocabulary. We will learn how it has developed over time, and investigate aspects of the meaning and pronunciation of words. Most of all, we will study how words are put together, so that students will be able to recognize and analyze unfamiliar words.
LIN203H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. Students will be expected to watch each asynchronous lecture video prior to the following tutorial. Tutorials will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule and will not be recorded. It is recommended that students have an electronic device with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Additionally, several online office hours (specific times TBD) will be available to students to drop in and ask any content and/or clarification questions.

ANT204H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues
ANT204H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A course focused on recent anthropological scholarship that seeks to understand and explain the transformation of contemporary societies and cultures. Topics may include some of the following: new patterns of global inequality, war and neo-colonialism, health and globalization, social justice and indigeneity, religious fundamentalism, gender inequalities, biotechnologies and society etc.
ANT204H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: For ANT204H, there will be a combination of synchronous and asynchronous lectures, with selected pre-recorded lectures which will be outlined on the syllabus. The lectures will be recorded and uploaded after each lecture to support students who would need a second listen. There will also be opportunities for students to participate in synchronous lectures through activities/breakout rooms when prompted by the Instructure.  Tutorials will be synchronous.

CLA204H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A survey of the myths and legends of ancient Greece (and their extension to Rome) with some consideration of their role in ancient and modern literature and art.

SOC204H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Sociology
SOC204H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the methods and issues of qualitative research, the theories, methods for data collection and analysis, and the personal and ethical issues relating to qualitative research. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
SOC204H1-F-20215.prerequisite: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1
SOC204H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone; PowerPoint.

Lectures and tutorials will be synchronous.

CRI205H1-F-20215.orgName: Criminology and Sociolegal Studies, Centre for (CRI)
CRI205H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the study of crime and criminal behaviour. The concept of crime, the process of law formation, and the academic domain of criminology. Theories of crime causation, methodologies used by criminologists, and the complex relationship between crime, the media and modern politics.
CRI205H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in those courses cancelled at any time. Contact the Program office (CrimSL@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about CRI prerequisites/exclusions.

FAH207H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology
FAH207H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the civilizations of Greece and Rome.
FAH207H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

ANT208H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health
ANT208H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to applied evolutionary medical anthropology. It explores evidence for the evolution of human vulnerability to disease across the life cycle (conception to death) and implications for health of contemporary populations in behavioral ecological, cross-cultural, health and healing systems, historical trauma, inter-sectionality, and climate change, lenses.
ANT208H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. They will be posted each week prior to synchronous lectures. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous, at their scheduled times (see Calendar). Students are expected to view recorded lectures prior to meeting virtually with their Teaching Assistant for online synchronous tutorials. For tutorials, it would be helpful for students to have access to a microphone and/or camera. Access to a microphone and/or camera would also be helpful if students want to meet with the instructor virtually during their synchronous office hours (see Syllabus).

POL208H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This introductory course examines some key themes and issues in global politics, including interstate war, human rights, international institutions, and the evolution of the global order.
POL208H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Students will be expected to do readings and listen to lectures before tutorial meetings.
  • Online class discussions will be held during the scheduled lecture meeting times to discuss topics in the lectures and to assist students with course material.
  • Tutorials will be held during the scheduled meeting times and delivered online synchronously.
  • Students require a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online tutorials and lectures.

HST209H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Health: Determinants of Health & Health Care
HST209H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A multidisciplinary approach to understanding perspectives in health, health equity, and primary health care. Themes include critical discussion of the measurements of health outcomes and the socioeconomic and political factors that affect health, including neglected and marginalized populations in Canada and globally.
HST209H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include small group discussions and as well as class presentations. It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials. 

Synchronous lecture sessions will be recorded for later viewing; tutorial sessions will not be recorded, but tutorial-related materials will be made available as much as possible.

BCH210H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Biochemistry I: Proteins, Lipids and Metabolism
BCH210H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Proteins, enzymes, membranes and the metabolism of carbohydrates and lipids. This course is intended for students who are NOT taking BCH242Y1 as part of their program.
BCH210H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Successful completion of (CHM135H1, CHM136H1)/CHM151Y1  NOTE: CHM1** with COURSE EXCLUSION TO CHM135H1 AND CHM136H1 meet the Prerequisite requirement for BCH210H1. CHM110H5 & CHM120H5 (UTM) are equivalent to CHM135H1 ONLY. CHMA10H3 & CHMA11H3 (UTSC) are equivalent to CHM135H1 ONLY. CHMB41H3/CHMB42H3 (UTSC) are equivalent to CHM136H1 ONLY.  CHM242H5 (UTM) is equivalent to CHM136H1 ONLY. Students with a SDF in CHM135H1/CHM136H1 are not permitted to enrol in BCH210H1 until a final passing grade (50%) appears on the transcript.
BCH210H1-F-20215.exclusion: BCH242Y1, [CHM361H5(UTM) and CHM362H5(UTM)], [BIOC12H3(UTSC) and BIOC13H3(UTSC)], CHMB62H3(UTSC)
BCH210H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
BCH210H1F is an Online - Synchronous course administered through Quercus.

Content lectures will be delivered asynchronously as pre-recorded online videos available on a weekly basis with accompanying questions to be answered in Quercus. Weekly quizzes based on the lecture content will be available for completion each week on Fridays, also through Quercus.  Synchronous overview lectures will be delivered each week on Quercus on Mondays from 10-11 am, but will be recorded for viewing at a later date/time. Students will have the opportunity to participate in synchronous and recorded, online tutorials once per week (Thursdays 3-5 pm or Fridays 9-11 am), which involve working through problems and Q&A with a tutorial TA using Blackboard Collaborate. 5% of the assessments will be for tutorial participation. Note – tutorial attendance is the only mandatory, synchronous portion requiring attendance for this course.

All material for lectures, tutorials and assignments will be available as downloadable pdf files through Quercus.

In addition to a high-speed internet connection for the viewing of lectures, participation of tutorials, and completion of online quizzes, students will also require internet search capability including the access to journal articles through the University of Toronto library network.  Assignments can be done offline but will require the use of word processing software and the submission of digital pdf files.  Students will also learn to use protein visualization tools either through the internet or by downloading free programs to their personal computers.

65% of the term work will be “take-home” assessments submitted at various points throughout the course. Online questions and quizzes completed on a weekly basis throughout the term will be worth 30%, and the remaining 5% will be for synchronous online participation during tutorials.

Blackboard Collaborate will also be used for online office hours (Thursdays and Fridays from 1-2 pm) for assistance with the content and questions regarding the assignments.

HPS210H1-F-20215.orgName: History and Philosophy of Science and Technology (HPS) (JHE) (JPH)
HPS210H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Case studies in the history of science from antiquity to 1800, including the revolutionary work of Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, Newton, Linnaeus, Lavoisier, and Herschel. The course is designed to be accessible to science students and non-scientists alike.
HPS210H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an Online Synchronous course.  

Lectures and PowerPoint will be uploaded to the course web site on a weekly basis (Tuesdays 12-2 and Thursdays 12-2) and the instructor will run two webinars (discussion, question and answer sessions) each week (Tuesdays 12-2 and Thursdays 12-2) scheduled so that students who are remote will also be able to participate in these sessions.

INI211H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This introductory course focuses on the process and craft of creative writing. Students will study short fiction, creative nonfiction and poetry by established writers, and learn to respond to works-in-progress by their peers. A variety of activities will help students generate, develop, and revise a portfolio of original creative work.
INI211H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and writing workshops are synchronous. Discussions of reading are asynchronous. Lectures and writing workshops will take place during the listed class time via video conference using Blackboard Collaborate through Quercus. Students will also need a Zoom account using their U of T email address. Students who cannot use Zoom and students who have accessibility needs should contact the instructor for accommodations.

EEB214H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Evolution and adaptation of life on Earth. Introduction to the theory of evolution by natural selection. Topics may include: evidence supporting the fact of evolution, and how evolutionary theory can help explain the world around us, such as how species are formed, and the evolution of sex, infanticide, and disease. For non-science students in all years and disciplines. For non-science students in all years and disciplines.
EEB214H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course is an online synchronous course with occasional review lectures recorded for asynchronous viewing and attendance will be mandatory.

POL214H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the study of Canadian government. Topics include institutions of governance: the constitution, machinery of government, charter of rights and freedom, and the electoral system.
POL214H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be delivered online synchronously and recordings will be available for students to view asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous, at their scheduled times.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

EEB215H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the scientific discipline that deals with threatened species and habitats. Topics include: biodiversity, extinction, threats, demography, genetic diversity, protecting, managing and restoring ecosystems (e.g., nature reserves, captive breeding, conservation corridors), sustainable development, and global warming. Ties between the study of conservation biology and environmental law, economics, and policy will also be covered. For non-science students in all years and disciplines. For non-science students in all years and disciplines.
EEB215H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course is an online course including both synchronous and asynchronous content. Lecture content will be posted as a series of videos in 20 min to one hour units. Students will have the opportunity to attend 1-2 hour live lectures/webinars once per week which will be posted following the live event. There is a required hour of synchronous tutorial content each week and attendance is mandatory.

ENG215H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the Canadian short story, this course emphasizes its rich variety of settings, subjects, and styles.

GGR217H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Considers the role of planning in shaping the urban landscape through historical and contemporary examples that illustrate the interplay of modernist and post-modernist approaches to city building. Traces the origins, competing rationalities and lingering effects of planning in the production of urban space. Broaches possibilities for engaging planning critically to address challenges of social and environmental justice in cities today.

HIS218H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A lecture-based course designed to introduce students to key moments and concepts in the field of environmental history since c. 1400. This course will track the reciprocal influence of humans and the non-human world since the so-called "Columbian Exchange," emphasizing the ways in which the non-human world-from plants, animals, and disease organisms to water, topography, and geography- have shaped human endeavours. At the same time, students will engage with many of the ways in which human beings have shaped the world around us, from empire and colonization, to industrial capitalism, nuclear power, and modern wildlife conservation.
HIS218H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online synchronously

RSM219H1-F-20215.courseDescription:
Basic introduction to financial reporting and analysis. Emphasis is on decision-making and interpretation of financial statements and how they can be used to plan a firm’s overall business activities through the use of real-world companies. Coverage includes the use of accounting information to prepare a basic set of financial statements. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.

Note: This course is normally taken in first year.
RSM219H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online.  This will be accompanied with asynchronous materials.

CHM220H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to thermodynamics; kinetics; phase equilibrium, properties of mixtures, chemical equilibrium, electrochemistry; introduction to quantum mechanics and spectroscopy. This course is recommended for students in life and health science programs that involve a small amount of chemistry. Students enrolled in any chemistry specialist program (including Biological Chemistry and Environmental Chemistry) or who will be including a substantial amount of chemistry in their degree (such as those following a chemistry major program), are strongly encouraged to take CHM222H1 and CHM223H1.

PSY220H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Contemporary areas of research in social psychology: social perception, attitudes, inter-personal relations, and group processes.
PSY220H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online. Tests will be held on May 13th 11am-1pm;  May 27th 11am-1pm; and June 10th 11am-1pm.

RSM220H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Foundations of financial reporting and analysis in Canada. Financial accounting topics are covered at an intermediate level, including both conceptual and technical aspects. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM220H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered in the following format.  Each lecture will be comprised of 1-hour of asynchronous pre-recorded video, and 1-hour of synchronous lecture.

STA220H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introductory course in statistical concepts and methods, emphasizing exploratory data analysis for univariate and bivariate data, sampling and experimental designs, basic probability models, estimation and tests of hypothesis in one-sample and comparative two-sample studies. A statistical computing package is used but no prior computing experience is assumed. Note: STA220H1does not count as a distribution requirement course.
STA220H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Grade 12 Mathematics and one University course in the physical, social, or life sciences
STA220H1-F-20215.exclusion: ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ GGR270H1/ PSY201H1/ SOC300Y1/ STA261H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ EEB225H1/ STAB22H3/ STAB57H3/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ ECO220Y5/ ECO227Y5/ STA258H5/ STA260H5
STA220H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be offered completely online. Lectures will be delivered online for at least some, if not all, of the scheduled lecture times. Details about the online course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Quercus and online class meeting tools including Bb Collaborate, Microsoft Teams and Zoom.

CDN221H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Culture and the Media in Canada
CDN221H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An exploration of the encounter between culture and mass communication in Canadian society. The course considers the role of major cultural institutions such as the CBC, the NFB, and their granting bodies. The emergence of new media and its relationship to mass media is also addressed.
CDN221H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be live-streamed and synchronous to enable real-time contact with the professor, the TA and classmates. Students are encouraged to participate online both verbally and using the chat function. The course requirements are two essays and a final assignment/exam. Students who have difficulties due to time zone differences may apply for recordings of the classes.  The professor and TA will be available through office hours or by appointment. Students need the ability to view PDFs or slides. The course will be conducted on Zoom.

POL222H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduces the foundations of quantitative empirical research methods - increasingly popular and important part of political science research and public policy debates - to enable you to interpret and evaluate the results of the studies that employ these methods. Topics include scientific study of politics, empirical research designs, and regression analysis.
POL222H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures are live-streamed and recorded, permitting synchronous delivery and asynchronous attendance.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online tutorials.

MAT223H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Systems of linear equations, matrix algebra, real vector spaces, subspaces, span, linear dependence and independence, bases, rank, inner products, orthogonality, orthogonal complements, Gram-Schmidt, linear transformations, determinants, Cramer's rule, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, eigenspaces, diagonalization.
MAT223H1-F-20215.exclusion: MATA22H3, MATA23H3, MAT223H5, MAT224H1, MAT240H1, MAT240H5, MAT247H1, MAT247H5
MAT223H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT224H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Fields, complex numbers, vector spaces over a field, linear transformations, matrix of a linear transformation, kernel, range, dimension theorem, isomorphisms, change of basis, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalizability, real and complex inner products, spectral theorem, adjoint/self-adjoint/normal linear operators, triangular form, nilpotent mappings, Jordan canonical form.
MAT224H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

LEC-0201.meetingStatusNotes:
April 16, 2021: Friday offering added.
February 26, 2021: Meeting Days/Times changed.

CRI225H1-F-20215.orgName: Criminology and Sociolegal Studies, Centre for (CRI)
CRI225H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The main principles and themes of Canadian criminal law; legal definitions of crime, requirements of a criminal act (actus reus), criminal intention (mens rea), causation and defences. The origins, goals and functioning of criminal law, and limits on the power of the state to criminalize behaviour.
CRI225H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in those courses cancelled at any time. Contact the Program Office (CrimSL@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about CRI prerequisites/exclusions.

LIN228H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Phonetics is a linguistics course that investigates the sounds most commonly used in languages from an articulatory and acoustic point of view, with practice in their recognition and production. Students will learn the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and practice transcribing a wide variety of speech sounds.
LIN228H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

SMC228H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.

ACT230H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to financial mathematics, interest measurement, present value calculation, annuity valuation, loan amortization, consumer financing arrangements, bond valuation. The course is aimed at a general audience who will not be continuing in the actuarial science program. Course manuals fee: $30.
ACT230H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online (per the meeting schedule) or pre-recorded. All livestreamed lectures will also be recorded for viewing.

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online lectures.

BIO230H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The genome is the "book of life," providing instructions to construct an organism. This course introduces genome biology and explores how the building blocks of life are networked into functioning organisms. We will investigate how cells perceive internal and external cues, how gene expression is shaped by this perception, and how these events give rise to tissues, organs, and whole organisms. (Lab Materials Fee: $15). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
BIO230H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Laboratory enrolment can be done on ACORN until the evening of Monday May 3rd. Late lab enrolment or lab changes must be done by emailing the BIO230H1 Office at bio230@utoronto.ca. You can find out your lab group (e.g., P0101A) by logging into Quercus and looking under the Groups section. The lab manual and all course information will be available on Quercus.
BIO230H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Delivery of lectures and practicals will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. The course instructor will provide details on Quercus.

CLA231H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A historical survey of the most significant features in the development of the civilization and state of ancient Rome from the mythical beginnings to the fourth century C.E.

LIN232H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The nature and organization of syntactic systems; their relation to semantic systems and the linguistic organization of discourse; practical work in linguistic analysis.
LIN232H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

PHL232H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to issues in the fundamental branches of philosophy: metaphysics, which considers the overall framework of reality; epistemology, or the theory of knowledge; and related problems in the philosophy of science. Topics in metaphysics may include: mind and body, causality, space and time, God, freedom and determinism; topics in epistemology may include perception, evidence, belief, truth, skepticism.
PHL232H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be live-streamed as per the schedule via BB Collaborate. Recordings of the lecture will be posted on Quercus for asynchronous viewing. A microphone will be required for participation in tutorials.

RLG232H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The role of film as a mediator of thought and experience concerning religious worldviews. The ways in which movies relate to humanity's quest to understand itself and its place in the universe are considered in this regard, along with the challenge which modernity presents to this task. Of central concern is the capacity of film to address religious issues through visual symbolic forms.
RLG232H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous course. Some or all lectures and class meetings will be livestreamed to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously, which registered students can access on their own time. Students will have the opportunity for weekly online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content and assignments. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources and Quercus tools, including Bb Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

ENG235H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to book-length sequential art, this course includes fictional and nonfictional comics, with a focus on formal properties such as narrative layout and text/art hybridity. Themes vary but may include superheros; auto/biography; the figure of the outsider; women in comics; alienation and youth; and war reporting.

WDW235H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Digital Humanities (DH) studies human culture -- art, literature, history, geography, religion -- using computational tools and methodologies, and at the same time studies digital technologies and communities through humanist lenses, as complex cultural objects shaped by wider social and political concerns and the ways we construct knowledge and meaning.
WDW235H1-F-20215.prerequisite: 4 FCEs at the 100 level, at least 1 FCE of which must be in Humanities

ENG237H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course explores speculative fiction that invents or extrapolates an inner or outer cosmology from the physical, life, social, and human sciences. Typical subjects include AI, alternative histories, cyberpunk, evolution, future and dying worlds, genetics, space/time travel, strange species, theories of everything, utopias, and dystopias.

STA237H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis I
STA237H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to probability using simulation and mathematical frameworks, with emphasis on the probability needed for more advanced study in statistical practice. Topics covered include probability spaces, random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, probability mass, density, and distribution functions, expectation and variance, independence, conditional probability, the law of large numbers, the central limit theorem, sampling distributions. Computer simulation will be taught and used extensively for calculations and to guide the theoretical development.
STA237H1-F-20215.exclusion: STA247H1, STA255H1, STA257H1, ECO227Y1, STAB52H3, STA256H5, ECO227Y5
STA237H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be offered completely online. Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online for at least some, if not all, of the scheduled meeting times. Details about the online course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Quercus and online class meeting tools including Bb Collaborate, Microsoft Teams and Zoom.

ACT240H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Interest, discount and present values, as applied to determine prices and values of annuities, mortgages, bonds, equities; loan repayment schedules and consumer finance payments in general; yield rates on investments given the costs on investments. Course manuals fee: $45.
ACT240H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online (per the meeting schedule) or pre-recorded. All livestreamed lectures will also be recorded for viewing.

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online lectures.

CIN240H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Course on special topics in Cinema Studies. Topics vary each year.
CIN240H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Both lectures and discussions will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting both synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) as per the meeting schedule. However, synchronous attendance will be necessary for participation grades, and asynchronous participation should be limited to either catching up on or reviewing materials. Weekly screenings will be online and asynchronous via MyMedia. Students will need a web camera, microphone, and high-speed internet connection for video conferencing, media screenings, and access to Quercus (discussion boards, BB collaborate, etc.).

PHL240H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Consciousness and its relation to the body; personal identity and survival; knowledge of other minds; psychological events and behaviour.
PHL240H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Pre-recorded lectures will be posted on Tuesdays for asynchronous viewing. The Thursday meeting section will be a discussion session that is livestreamed using BB Collaborate. A microphone and camera are required for participation.

PSY240H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A critical survey of concepts, theories, and the state of research in the area of psychopathology and therapeutic methods.
PSY240H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during weekly scheduled meetings that will be available through an online platform. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and tests. All course assessments will be conducted online.

SOC240H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course asks students to think critically about the role of law in society, and to develop a sociological understanding of law and legal institutions. The course will include theoretical approaches to understanding the role of law and legal authority, and the constitutive ways in which law affects, shapes, and is negotiated in everyday life. In addition, attention will be paid to the legal profession, including empirical research on lawyers, legal careers, and their relationship to fields of practice, with an emphasis on the relationship between the structure of the legal profession and law as a democratic institution.
SOC240H1-F-20215.exclusion: SOC293H1 (Topics: Sociology of Law), offered in Summer 2018, Winter 2019, Summer 2019; SOC396H1 (Topics: Sociology of Law), offered in Winter 2013
SOC240H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (MS Teams/Zoom); camera & microphone.

Lectures & slides posted on Mondays & Wednesdays; readings on Quercus

IRE242H1-F-20215.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE242H1-F-20215.courseTitle: HRM for Industrial Relations and HR Professionals
IRE242H1-F-20215.courseDescription:
This course explores the relationship between human resource management, employment relations, and industrial relations. Extensive practical course work will expose students to the functions human resource professionals execute to recruit, select, compensate, train, and evaluate the performance of employees. The course prepares students for advanced HR topics in upper level IRE courses.

Note: Course will not count towards Rotman Commerce program requirements.
IRE242H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Industrial Relations & Human Resources program (ASMAJ1536, ASSPE1536)
IRE242H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in IRE courses cancelled at any time. For course details click on the course code in the timetable below and review the course description, prerequisites etc. before enrolling in a IRE course. Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about IRE courses.

SOC243H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course examines (1) the social causes of illness and disease, (2) the experience of illness, and social processes that shape both of these issues, including medicalization. It focuses on population health, the relation between agency and structure, and macro-micro connections. Professional health care is discussed to the extent that it provides context for analyses of illness patterns and experiences.
SOC243H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Quercus (Zoom); camera & microphone; lectures will be asynchronous; discussions will be synchronous during scheduled class times as per timetable.

IRE244H1-F-20215.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE244H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the institutions, issues and legislation affecting the employment relationship in the public and private sectors in Canada, with emphasis on collective bargaining. The economic and political environment, history of the labour movement, union organization, certification, contract negotiation, strikes, dispute resolution, contract administration and grievances.
IRE244H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Industrial Relations & Human Resources program (ASSPE1536/ASMAJ1536) or 4.0 or more FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3.
IRE244H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in IRE courses cancelled at any time. For course details click on the course code in the timetable below and review the course description, prerequisites etc. before enrolling in a IRE course. Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about IRE courses.

FRE245H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to French Cultural and Literary Studies
FRE245H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course is a practical introduction to concepts, methods and problems of literary analysis as well as an overview of French artistic culture. Using elements of comparison from fine arts, contemporary and popular culture (including novels and movies) and a variety of emblematic works of French and Francophone literatures (among others: essays by Voltaire, Montesquieu and Simone de Beauvoir; poems by Ronsard, Hugo, Baudelaire and Césaire; excerpts from novels by George Sand, Albert Camus and Patrick Chamoiseau), its objective is to provide students with a practical introduction to the tools of literary analysis, but also to help them better read, understand and appreciate literary texts.
FRE245H1-F-20215.prerequisite: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.
FRE245H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: This is a 6-hour course (4-hr lecture, 2-hr tutorial). Students will be assigned a tutorial by the instructor at the beginning of classes. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

HST250H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Research Methods in Health Studies
HST250H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Offers students in Health Studies a basic understanding of research design and data collection on health topics. Also assesses the usefulness of research and data collection in the formation of health policy.
HST250H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include small group discussions and as well as class presentations. It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials.

PHY250H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introductory course in Electromagnetism. Topics include: Point charges, Coulomb’s law, electrostatic field and potential, Gauss's Law, conductors, electrostatic energy, magnetostatics, Ampere's Law, Biot-Savart Law, the Lorentz Force Law, Faraday’s Law, Maxwell's equations in free space.
PHY250H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an on-line course. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion) will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Tutorials will follow the same principle. Some synchronous attendance may be required, in particular for assessments. Further details will be provided at a later date.

AST251H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Scholarly discussion of the probability that there are planets with life elsewhere in the universe, from the perspective of current ideas concerning the origin and evolution of the universe, the solar system and life. Search techniques and possibilities for interstellar travel and space colonies are discussed.
AST251H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, synchronous course, with ~2 hours of lecturing with demos and activities provided on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 6-8 pm. The presentations will be recorded to allow review and asynchronous attendance of the classes. Students will also have the opportunity via 1 hour synchronous online tutorials held approximately once per week to ask questions and get clarifications about lectures and course content. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate Ultra.

ENG252H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to Canadian literature, exploring works in poetry, prose, and drama from early to recent times.

SDS255H1-F-20215.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS255H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An interdisciplinary examination of sexuality across cultures and periods. How are sexualities represented? How are they suppressed or celebrated? How and why are they labeled as straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual, queer, or perverse? How do sexualities change with race/ethnicity, class, gender, and geographies?
SDS255H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures may consist of both synchronous and asynchronous components. For example, some lectures may be delivered asynchronously, while some assessments or discussions may be held synchronously. It is recommended that students have access to a computer or phone with working microphone to participate in online activities.

Additional delivery information will be provided in the course syllabus.

EAS256H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A survey of major works in premodern Chinese literature, including poetry, essays, and short narratives from the pre-Qin through Tang eras (11th century BCE - 10th century CE).
EAS256H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must participate synchronously at the scheduled times.

PHY256H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Failures of classical physics; the Quantum revolution; Stern-Gerlach effect; harmonic oscillator; uncertainty principle; interference packets; scattering and tunneling in one-dimension.
PHY256H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an on-line course. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion) will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Tutorials will follow the same principle. Some synchronous attendance may be required, in particular for assessments. Further details will be provided at a later date.

STA257H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A mathematically rigorous introduction to probability, with applications chosen to introduce concepts of statistical inference. Probability and expectation, discrete and continuous random variables and vectors, distribution and density functions, the law of large numbers. The binomial, geometric, Poisson, and normal distributions. The Central Limit Theorem. (Note: STA257H1 does not count as a distribution requirement course).
STA257H1-F-20215.exclusion: ECO227Y1, STA237H1, STA247H1, MAT377H1, STAB52H3, STA256H5, ECO227Y5
STA257H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be offered completely online. Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online for at least some, if not all, of the scheduled meeting times. Details about the online course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Quercus and online class meeting tools including Bb Collaborate, Microsoft Teams and Zoom.

CIN260H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Course on selected topics in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "New Media."
CIN260H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online synchronously per meeting schedule. Screenings will be online and asynchronous, but will be coordinated with lectures. Students need access to high-speed internet service and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

LEC-0101.subtitle: From Buddy Film to Bromance: Homoeroticism in Cinema

IRE260H1-F-20215.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE260H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the nature of organizations and the behaviour of individuals and groups within organizations, including topics such as culture and diversity, reward systems, motivation, leadership, politics, communication, decision-making, conflict and group processes. Not recommended for students in Commerce programs.
IRE260H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Industrial Relations & Human Resources program (ASSPE1536/ASMAJ1536) or 4.0 or more FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3
IRE260H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in IRE courses cancelled at any time. For course details click on the course code in the timetable below and review the course description, prerequisites etc. before enrolling in a IRE course. Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about IRE courses.

PSY260H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Concepts, theories, and applications of classical and contemporary learning theories, including classical and operant conditioning. Current theories of the physiological and anatomical basis of learning and memory, including synaptic plasticity, the role of the hippocampus, amygdala, frontal cortex and other brain regions. Theories will be related to a practical understanding and applications such as drug addiction, phobias and other disorders.
PSY260H1-F-20215.prerequisite: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program
