PSY260H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lecture recordings will be available online for students to view asynchronously. Opportunities for synchronous activities (e.g. virtual office hours) will be available but optional or an asynchronous option will also be made available. Students will be able complete the course entirely asynchronously without it adversely impacting their mark.

RSM260H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Theoretical ideas and practical applications concerning the behaviour of individuals and groups in organizations. We explore relevant topics for management: motivation, personality, perception, decision-making, groups, and negotiation. A fee of $10 will be charged to your student account for a simulation handbook. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM260H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be offered primarily asynchronously each week.  There will be 3 times during the term that students will need to connect synchronously to the class (details to be provided via the Quercus page).

NMC263H1-F-20215.courseTitle: The Archaeology of Gods, Ghosts, Witches and Demons
NMC263H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This class investigates archaeological traces of human interaction with the supernatural world in the ancient Near East, including figurines, temples, skulls, statues, and cylinder seals. In order to contextualize different ways of thinking about other worlds, we also look at cross-cultural comparisons ranging from Africa to the Americas.
NMC263H1-F-20215.recommendedPreparation:
NMC102H1

Breadth Requirements: Thought, Belief and Behaviour (2)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities
NMC263H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: It is highly desirable that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Class will consist of prerecorded narrated ppts and tutorials. A selection of tutorial times will be offered. Tutorials  will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings.

HIS264H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course introduces key issues in Canadian history and foundational principles of historical analysis. It is primarily designed for potential History majors/specialists. It is not a comprehensive survey. Examples serve to deepen analysis and introduce important methods and debates, preparing students for upper year courses in Canadian history.

HMB265H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to classical and modern methods of genetic analysis. Topics include Mendelian genetics, the genetics of human population and disease, genomics, and applications of genetics to human society.
HMB265H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Lecture recordings consisting of voiced-over PowerPoint presentations will also be posted on Quercus.  Tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.  Exams and tutorial quizzes will be synchronous (live) and delivered online per the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

enrollmentControls.adminOrgName: Department of Cell and Systems Biology
Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathobiology

FAH270H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A survey of architecture from pre-history to the start of modernism, with attention given to the ways in which architecture shapes human experience.
FAH270H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

PSY270H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to research and theory on the neural and cognitive architecture of attention, memory, language, thinking and reasoning.
PSY270H1-F-20215.prerequisite: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program
PSY270H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Synchronous office hours and review sessions will be scheduled throughout the term. It is recommended that students have a computer, a microphone, and internet access in order to participate in online activities.

RSM270H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the management of business processes that convert inputs (labor, material, equipment) into outputs (goods and services) for internal and external markets. Topics include aggregate planning, inventory processes, supply chain management and service operations management. Presents modern quantitative and computing tools necessary for in-depth operational design and analysis. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM270H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

SOC270H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course covers the fundamentals of the social network perspective, including a short introduction to social network theory and a survey of major findings in social network research. We will study how patterns of relations between social actors develop and how they affect outcomes such as health, status attainment, and inequality. Students will write a proposal to conduct research from a social network perspective.
SOC270H1-F-20215.exclusion: SOC355H1, SOC294H1 (Topics: Introduction to Social Networks) offered in Winter 2018 and Winter 2020
SOC270H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone.

Lectures uploaded by 12 p.m., on Tuesdays and will be available for one week.

PHL271H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Justifications for the legal enforcement of morality; particular ethical issues arising out of the intersection of law and morality, such as punishment, freedom of expression and censorship, autonomy and paternalism, constitutional protection of human rights.
PHL271H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

FRE272H1-F-20215.courseTitle: The French Language: A Linguistic Introduction
FRE272H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A general introduction to the structure of French language, from a linguistic perspective. Students will become acquainted with the various components of the language (sound, meaning, word formation, sentence structure) through detailed description and basic analysis of Canadian and European varieties of French. Students will also be introduced to the study of French in the context of bilingualism (second language acquisition, sociolinguistics). This course is mandatory in all specialist and major programs.
FRE272H1-F-20215.prerequisite: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test
FRE272H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: This is a 6-hour course (4-hr lecture, 2-hr tutorial). Students will be assigned a tutorial by the instructor at the beginning of classes. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

GGR272H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to digital mapping and spatial analysis using geographic information systems (GIS). Students learn how to use GIS software to find, edit, analyze and map geographic data to create their own maps, analyze geographic problems and use techniques that can be applied to a variety of subject areas.

LEC-0101.meetingStatusNotes: March 3, 2021: Contact hours per week changed.

EAS274H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Through various forms of popular culture in the 20th century, this course explores the cultural contexts and social trajectories of China, Japan and Korea. Forms of popular culture studied include art, visual culture, consumer habits, foodways, advertising, music, and fashion.
EAS274H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must participate synchronously at the scheduled times.

NMC277H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Topics in Near & Middle Eastern Civilizations
NMC277H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Topics vary from year to year, depending on instructor.
NMC277H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
NMC277H1F LEC0201: The course explores the history of art and technology through tracing the development of various art objects as a result of interactions between the Islamic world, China, and Europe. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.  

NMC277H1F LEC0301: Lectures will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. Students will be expected to do assigned readings prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Lecture slides will be made available for students to download.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Love and Sex in the Ancient Near East

LEC-0201.subtitle: Connected: The Islamic World, China, and Europe

LEC-0301.subtitle: Race and Slavery in the Islamic World

LEC-0401.subtitle: Champions and Kings: From Samson to Solomon in the Hebrew Bible

LEC-0501.subtitle: Kurdish Women: History, Resistance & Popular Culture

NMC278H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to the Modern Middle East
NMC278H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The emergence of modern states in the Middle East, against a background of empire, world wars, and national and religious movements. Students will learn why the modern map looks the way it does, and how Middle Eastern peoples' self-identifications have changed over the past 200 years.

PHL281H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the study of moral and legal problems in medical practice and in biomedical research; the development of health policy. Topics include: concepts of health and disease, patient rights, informed consent, allocation of scarce resources, euthanasia, abortion, genetic and reproductive technologies, human research, and mental health.
PHL281H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

EAS284H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course offers a critical examination of 20th-century Chinese literature, with a focus on the important developments of literary writing over time, from the inception of New Literature in the 1910s, the development of realism and modernism in the 1930s, to the emergency of post-revolution and postmodernist writings in the 1990s. Emphasis is placed on generating a dialogue on interpretations of key works.

NFS284H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introductory course to provide the fundamentals of human nutrition to enable students to understand and think critically about the complex interrelationships between food, nutrition, health and the environment.
NFS284H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an online, synchronous course with Lectures on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 1-4pm. 
Students will have the opportunity to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. 
Tutorials will be weekly online synchronous seminars and a schedule will be provided during the first week of classes.

DRM288H1-F-20215.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM288H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Effective communication is a pivotal skill when public speaking, persuasive discourse, and personal presence are key to success. In this introductory course, students will strengthen and develop confidence in a supportive, playful, highly participatory and collaborative environment. This course is suited to students in professional programs or for those who would like to learn a full range of communication skills. Exploration of language structure, argumentation, grounding, alignment, vocal resonance, clarity and effective listening will be part of each class with an emphasis on enhancing individual potential.
DRM288H1-F-20215.exclusion: DRM286H1 (Special Topics in Drama: Introduction to Communications), offered in Summer 2013, Summer 2014, Summer 2015, Summer 2016, Summer 2017, Summer 2018, Summer 2019, and Summer 2020.
DRM288H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

FCS292H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Special Topics in French Cultural Studies I
FCS292H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The relation of French popular culture to society. For more information, see http://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/french_cultural_studies

LEC-0101.subtitle: Love, Sex and Desire in French Literature and Cinema

PCL297H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A formal opportunity to gain hands-on experience and develop their skills within a research laboratory setting. Students will have a chance to become familiar and efficient at good lab practices, develop critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and developing trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PCL297H1-F-20215.prerequisite: None; Permission of Faculty Supervisor and Departmental Undergraduate Coordinator required.
PCL297H1-F-20215.recommendedPreparation: Completion of at least first year of Life Sciences program.
PCL297H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students enroll in this course through the Department. Please contact course coordinator: Dr. Hamadani at anita.hamadanizadeh@utoronto.ca
PCL297H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an independent research project course with no formal lecture schedule. Students are required to secure their own supervisor for the course. 

If Public Health and institutional guidelines allow, and by mutual agreement of the student and faculty supervisor, in-person meetings may be arranged.

HMB300H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This neuroscience course focuses on higher brain functions and the mechanisms underlying human and animal behaviours. Topics may include the emerging role of the gut microbiome's impact on behaviour, pathogens that alter neuronal development and the biological basis of mindfulness and placebos. In addition, the impact that exercise and sleep play in modulating these behaviours are examined. Common experimental techniques used in neuroscience research such as brain imaging and cellular genetics are emphasized.

HPS300H1-F-20215.orgName: History and Philosophy of Science and Technology (HPS) (JHE) (JPH)
HPS300H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Topics in History and Philosophy of Science and Technology

INI300H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Strategic Writing in Business and the Professions: Theory and Practice
INI300H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Aims to teach students to recognize the rhetoric of the professional workplace and to communicate strategically and ethically using written and oral discourse appropriate to business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central component of the course.
INI300H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
An asynchronous 2 hour lecture and practice exercises will be posted well in advance; students will be a guaranteed a one hour synchronous meeting twice per week with the understanding that if necessary, more time will be dedicated.

The synchronous portion shall be recorded.

Students are reminded that this is a fast-paced intensive course.

PSL300H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Principles of neurophysiology, endocrinology and reproductive physiology for students enroled in Life Science programs.
PSL300H1-F-20215.recommendedPreparation: BIO130H1/BIO150Y1; CHM138H1/CHM151Y1; and 1 FCE from any of the following: MAT135H1, MAT136H1, MAT135Y1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, PHY131H1, PHY132H, PHY151H1, PHY152H1
PSL300H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online course. Lectures will be posted online (4-6 hours/week). Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2 hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content (the sessions will be recorded). Students need the ability to view PDF files and must have access to Quercus (which includes access to Blackboard Collaborate). The assessment will take place during scheduled class time. The final assessment date and time will be announced by the Faculty of Registrar’s office.
PSL300H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: The lecture videos will be posted to watch asynchronously but help session & test will run synchronously. This means students have to ensure they are available Tuesday and Thursday 5-7 p.m. (Toronto Time).

HMB302H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Laboratory and lecture course studying the structure of the cell, various tissues and organ systems. Emphasis is on functional morphology and the adaptive response (including the inflammatory reaction) by comparing histological sections of normal tissues and organs with common diseases including neoplasia, respiratory, and liver disease. (Lab Materials Fee: $27)
HMB302H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be asynchronous: given as 2-hr online videos twice a week posted on Wednesdays and Fridays. 

Tutorials are synchronous, Wednesdays and Fridays from 1:00pm to 3:00pm via Blackboard Collaborate. Live with the TAs and prof! Bell-Ringer Tests: synchronous, during their normal tutorial time.¾ There will be 2 timed exams.

LAS302H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The goal of this course is to critically explore debates and perspectives on development and on the politics of inequality in Latin American contexts. Topics of the course may vary, depending on the needs of the program and the interests of students and instructors.
LAS302H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This will be an intensive online hybrid course. Students will be expected to complete assignments asynchronously (estimate about 4 hours/week): readings, videos, exercises, writing, etc. during the first weeks of the course. The course will have one week of intensive mandatory online synchronous meetings, from Monday, May 31 to Friday, June 4 from 2:00 to 4:00 PM for presentations and discussions. Students will continue to work asynchronously for the last part of the course.

POL302Y1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course explores China’s efforts to construct a modern and effective political order in the face of powerful demographic and revolutionary challenges. The clash between competing ideologies, political and social movements and institutional alternatives in the context of rapid social and economic change are analyzed.
POL302Y1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: • Lectures will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule.

STA302H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to data analysis with a focus on regression. Initial Examination of data. Correlation. Simple and multiple regression models using least squares. Inference for regression parameters, confidence and prediction intervals. Diagnostics and remedial measures. Interactions and dummy variables. Variable selection. Least squares estimation and inference for non-linear regression.
STA302H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be offered completely online. Lectures will be delivered online for at least some, if not all, of the scheduled lecture times. Details about the online course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Quercus and online class meeting tools including Bb Collaborate, Microsoft Teams and Zoom.

STA304H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Design of surveys, sources of bias, randomized response surveys. Techniques of sampling; stratification, clustering, unequal probability selection. Sampling inference, estimates of population mean and variances, ratio estimation. Observational data; correlation vs. causation, missing data, sources of bias.
STA304H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ GGR270H1/ PSY201H1/ SOC300H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA255H1/ STA261H1/ STA248H1/ STA238H1/ STA288H1/ EEB225H1/ STAB22H3/ STAB57H3/ STA220H5/ STA258H5/ STA260H5/ ECO220Y5/ ECO227Y5
STA304H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be offered completely online. Lectures will be delivered online for at least some, if not all, of the scheduled lecture times. Details about the online course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Quercus and online class meeting tools including Bb Collaborate, Microsoft Teams and Zoom.

TRN305Y1-F-20215.courseDescription: The nature and justification of legal rules as preparation for the study of basic principles of law governing the relations between individual citizens, and the relations between individual citizens and the state. A selection of contract, tort, criminal and administrative law. Restricted to students in the major program Ethics, Society, and Law.
TRN305Y1-F-20215.prerequisite: Active in ASMAJ1618 only if enrolling in the Fall/Winter session. A student must be in third or fourth year.
TRN305Y1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This seminar will be delivered online synchronous model, allowing students to participate online in real time. 

Students must have access to Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate and/or MS Teams and a device that supports audio and video.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

MUS306H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A selected survey of North American popular music from the 1930s through present. Students will develop a critical framework for listening to and analyzing popular music in historical and social context by focusing on aspects of performance, representation, composition, mass media, aesthetics, and commodification. No prior background in music or ability to read music is required.

INI308H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Selected Topics in Writing and Rhetoric
INI308H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Courses on selected topics in Writing and Rhetoric.
INI308H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Course Description for Summer 2021: This course introduces students to works by some of the most influential literary journalists of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Classes will be devoted to individual literary-journalistic genres: the personal essay, the profile, the polemic, the memoir, literary reportage, and cultural criticism. Students will look closely at key writers who worked across these genres: George Orwell, James Baldwin, Joan Didion, Joyce Carol Oates. Over the semester, students will develop and write a feature-length work of literary journalism in a genre of their choice, to be refined through peer workshop and instructor feedback.
INI308H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Each class will consist of an asynchronous video, which students will watch on their own time, and a synchronous class discussion, for which attendance is mandatory and participation is strongly encouraged. 

Students will not be able to access recordings from the online-synchronous parts of the course but will be expected to access and view the asynchronous video content prior to each class discussion. 

Students will need a computer with Internet access, a webcam and microphone to participate verbally in synchronous class discussions.

PSY308H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A lecture course providing in-depth examination of specific topics/themes relating to Psychology. Content in any given year depends on instructor. Priority is given to PSY Major program students during the first enrolment period.
PSY308H1-F-20215.prerequisite: PSY100H1, PSY201H1 (or exclusion), and one further 200-level PSY half-course
PSY308H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online asynchronously, though live synchronous class discussions and/or office hours will be available each week at a specific time and day.  Participation in synchronous activities will be optional and asynchronous options will also be made available. All course assessments will be conducted online. Students will be able to complete the course entirely asynchronously without it adversely impacting their mark.

SOC311H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Immigration and Race Relations in Canada
SOC311H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Examines the economic, social, cultural and political impacts of 20th century immigration in Canada, and emerging race and ethnic relations. Topics include immigration policy; population impact; community formation; labour markets; enclave economies; welfare use by immigrants; the criminal justice system; racial conflict; multiculturalism and race; and equity policies.
SOC311H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (Zoom); camera & microphone.

Pre-recorded lectures will be released at least 24 hours in advance of the class, which will then be discussed during class time.

ITA312H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Mediaeval Italian Literature in Translation: Petrarch and Boccaccio
ITA312H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A study of Petrarch's Canzoniere and of Boccaccio's Decameron in relation to later Middle Ages. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
ITA312H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS

Lectures and any discussions and/or activities will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students will need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate) and the ability to use MS Teams and/or Zoom.

It is necessary that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Students are expected to have cameras on all the time.

PHL313H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Central philosophical problems arising in the early modern period.
PHL313H1-F-20215.prerequisite: PHL210Y1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy
PHL313H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be live-streamed on Zoom. Recordings will be posted online for asynchronous viewing.

PSY313H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Age changes in sensory and perceptual processes, motor skill, learning, memory, and personality. Theory, methodological problems, social, cultural, and environmental influences that shape behaviour and attitudes towards and among the elderly.
PSY313H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling approximately 4-5 hours/week. Students are expected to collaborate with a small group of students to discuss important questions related to real-life applications of course material. This collaboration can be done asynchronously or synchronously according to students' preferences. Students will have the option of attending a synchronous feedback conference about their written assignments with the instructor or TA. It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera to participate.

EAS314H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Exploration of literature, film, and other cultural production related to the atomic bombing and other nuclear catastrophes from transnational, inter-Asia, and transpacific perspectives. Primarily focuses on, but not necessarily limited to, the cultural texts, intellectual concepts, and social thoughts generated out of the history of Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic destruction.
EAS314H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students are expected to participate synchronously at the scheduled times. Students who cannot attend synchronously for a reason such as time zone difference may request that recorded material be made available to them.

ECO314H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course surveys important features of energy markets and related environmental challenges. One of the central objectives is to provide an understanding of the key economic tools needed to analyse these markets. A related objective is the development of a framework for understanding the public discourse on energy and the environment. Topics include: the hydrocarbon economy (oil, natural gas and coal), electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, renewable energy, conservation, carbon taxes and ‘cap-and-trade’.
ECO314H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
ECO314H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures are conducted synchronously. These are recorded and posted online. There will be no in-person sessions. Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled time-slot. You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

POL317H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Draws from the major theoretical traditions in public policy and policymaking of the advanced industrial world, and applies these theories in understanding the developing world context and the new challenges of global change.
POL317H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate.
  • Lectures are live-streamed and recorded, permitting synchronous delivery and asynchronous attendance.

SMC317H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Applying the thought of key media theorists (Innis, McLuhan, Habermas, Fiske, etc.) to the historical symbiosis between music and media, students in this course explore communications from oral storytelling to YouTube, as well as examine the relationship between music and other arts.
SMC317H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: An exploration of diverse media narratives to address cultural approaches to trauma.
SMC317H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via live webinars will be made available and are optional. Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

ECO320H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law).
ECO320H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

PSY321H1-F-20215.courseDescription: One of the hallmarks of human behaviour is its diversity. Some of the ways in which we differ are thought to be relatively idiosyncratic (e.g., specific aspects of personality), whereas others are fairly systematic. Cultural psychology is one area of research in human behaviour that examines systematic differences resulting from individuals’ cultural backgrounds. This course will introduce you to the consideration of cultural variation in the study of human thought and behaviour.
PSY321H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be an online, asynchronous course. Lecture videos will be recorded and uploaded to the course website each week. Students will have the opportunity to attend synchronous office hours each week to ask questions and get feedback. There will also be opportunities for synchronous activities with your classmates. All course assessments will be conducted online.

CRI322H1-F-20215.orgName: Criminology and Sociolegal Studies, Centre for (CRI)
CRI322H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course examines the intersections between social inequality and the criminal justice system in Canada and internationally. The course explores how factors such as race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation and religion influence perceptions of and experiences with crime and criminal justice.
CRI322H1-F-20215.exclusion: CRI391H1 (Topics in Criminology and Sociolegal Studies: Inequality and Criminal Justice), offered in Winter 2018, Summer 2018, Summer 2019, Winter 2020, SOC322H5
CRI322H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in those courses cancelled at any time. Contact the Program Office (CrimSL@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about CRI prerequisites/exclusions.

PHL322H1-F-20215.courseDescription: German and French philosophy after World War II, focusing on such topics as: debates about humanism, hermeneutics, critical theory, the structuralist movement, its successors such as deconstruction. Typical authors: Heidegger, Gadamer, Habermas, Levi-Strauss, Foucault, Derrida.
PHL322H1-F-20215.prerequisite: PHL217H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy
PHL322H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

ENG323H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A study of selected novels of Jane Austen and of works by such contemporaries as Radcliffe, Godwin, Wollstonecraft, Wordsworth, Edgeworth, Scott, and Shelley, in the context of the complex literary, social, and political relationships of that time.

NEW324H1-F-20215.courseTitle: The Contemporary Caribbean in a Global Context
NEW324H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This upper level course examines the interplay between wider global processes and intra-regional responses that together help shape contemporary Caribbean realities. Topics include: economic crisis and structural adjustment; tourism; the agricultural sector; the Caribbean Single Market and Economy; migration and diaspora.
NEW324H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be available synchronously (live) at the scheduled course time and asynchronously (recorded). Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

RSM324H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course emphasises the fundamentals of the Canadian tax system. Included are topics, such as, residence of corporations and individuals, effective tax rates for corporations and individuals, business income, integration, capital gains and losses, to name a few. A key objective of this course is to assist students in learning to read, interpret and apply provisions of the Income Tax Act to practical problems and cases. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM324H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lecture will run for 2 hours asynchronously and 1 hour synchronously each class. The synchronous classes will be run via Blackboard Collaborate.

ECO325H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A development of the microeconomic foundations of macroeconomic theory to expand students' analytic skills by constructing and solving macroeconomic models. Topics may include: dynamic choice, neoclassical growth theory, uncertainty and rational expectations, business cycles, as well as fiscal and monetary policy.
ECO325H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

POL326Y1-F-20215.courseDescription: The foreign policy of the United States: tradition and context of American decision-making, the process by which it is formulated, application to a number of specific regions and problems in the world.
POL326Y1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: • Lectures are live-streamed and recorded, permitting synchronous delivery and asynchronous attendance.

CSB329H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Stem Cell Biology: Developmental Models and Cell-based Therapeutics
CSB329H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Stem cells provide the basis for cellular diversity in multicellular organisms and have enormous therapeutic potential in regenerative medicine. The course will introduce students to the differences and similarities between stem cells from different organisms, their roles throughout development and therapeutic potential.
CSB329H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: No special hardware or software is required. A laptop/PC/mobile with internet connection is sufficient.

ENG329H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course explores six or more works by at least four British contemporary writers of fiction.

GGR329H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Explores the changing global geographies of food by tracing international movements of food through both mainstream and 'alternative' supply chains. The implications for sustainability, food security, community autonomy and health are investigated.
GGR329H1-F-20215.recommendedPreparation: 8.0 FCE's including 1.0 FCE in Geography (SOC SCI/BR=3)

ECO331H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Ample empirical and experimental evidence suggests significant departures from classical assumptions of economic behaviour. For example, humans are neither always perfectly rational nor always self interested. This course describes systematic ways in which behaviour deviates from neoclassical assumptions, generating new, and hopefully more realistic behavioural assumptions that have broad empirical, theoretical and policy implications.
ECO331H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
ECO331H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be predominately asynchronous, with some minor synchronous elements. Lectures will be posted as online videos, and students will have the chance to engage with the course material and each other through online discussion boards, and will complete all work digitally. Students will have flexibility in the timing of their course work, but will need to keep up to date with the course material, and be actively participating in the course on a regular basis, much like with a traditional course. Additionally, some course elements (participation in experiments), will require students to be available during one of several scheduled times. Students will need reliable Internet access via a computer with a working microphone.

RSM332H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to capital market theory explaining how financial securities are priced. Topics covered include the time and risk value of money, the use of discounted cash flow techniques, efficient set theory, asset pricing and market efficiency. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM332H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

ECO333H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Spatial economic theory and urban public policy: firms and individuals in partial and general equilibrium, land development and land-use controls, urban transportation, efficiency and equity in spending and taxing.
ECO333H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be online asynchronous. Tutorials will be online synchronous and recorded for asynchronous viewing. There will be synchronous online class discussions once per week and regular online office hours. Exams will be online synchronous.

NEW333H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Explores some important connections between Cognitive Science and Buddhism. In particular it will examine the insights of cognitive science into central Buddhist concepts such as wisdom, mindfulness, meditation, insight and self-control, as well as related concepts such as flow and mystical experience.
NEW333H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures are pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Students meet online for a half-hour block during the scheduled class time for Town Halls. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365 and BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

CDN335H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An interdisciplinary course that interrogates the constitution of blackness in Canada. Students will study race and ethnic relations, alongside other identity formations such as class, gender and sexuality. Topics to be addressed include media, education, law, immigration and mobility, urbanism, work, political representation and the arts.
CDN335H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be held online and will have both asynchronous and synchronous elements. For example, some lectures & material may be delivered asynchronously, while discussions may be held synchronously. It is recommended that students have access to a microphone and camera to participate in online activities.

CIN340H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice
CIN340H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
CIN340H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be online synchronous and will include PowerPoint presentations, film clips, and in-class discussions. Live-streamed lectures will be recorded, but synchronous participation is mandatory. Screenings will be online asynchronous and can be accessed through the course website. Students will need a computer, webcam, microphone, and high-speed internet access to use Quercus and BB Collaborate.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Learning the Unteachable: Cinema and Aesthetic Education

CJS340H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Mizrahim in Israel: History, Politics, and Culture
CJS340H1-F-20215.courseDescription: What is the significance of the designation “Mizrahi” in Israel today? Does it refer to people who share a common geographical and ethnic origin or does it indicate a shared worldview that draws upon Middle Eastern Arabic culture? What are its relations with other terms, such as “Sephardi,” “Oriental,” or “Levantine”? What kind of political membership does it entail? Does it possess a certain cultural, religious, or political vocabulary? And, ultimately, does the diasporic concept of “Mizrahiyut” (mizrahiness) undermine national homogeneity or rather facilitate and enable its enforcement?
CJS340H1-F-20215.exclusion: CJS390H1 (Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Mizrahim in Israel: History, Politics, and Culture), offered in Summer 2017
CJS340H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, synchronous course. Students are expected to be logged into the course on Mondays and Thursdays from 12pm-2pm EST every week, when they will be virtually attending lectures, delivered in real time, and participating in online discussions, again, in real time. All readings and audio/visual materials will be posted on course website.

CRI340H1-F-20215.orgName: Criminology and Sociolegal Studies, Centre for (CRI)
CRI340H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The study of punishment from historical and philosophical perspectives, with a focus on contemporary Canadian policy issues. Topics covered include penal theory, prisons and non-carceral forms of punishment, and the goals of penal reform.
CRI340H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in those courses cancelled at any time. Contact the Program Office (CrimSL@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about CRI prerequisites/exclusions.

EAS340H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course explores issues of identity, self, and community in a broad exploration of cultural transformation in China.
EAS340H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must participate synchronously at the scheduled times.

ENG340H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A study of plays in English by such dramatists as Wilde, Yeats, Shaw, Synge, Glaspell, Hughes, O'Neill, as well as plays in translation by such dramatists as Ibsen, Chekhov, Strindberg, Pirandello.

IMM340H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course introduces the basic principles and key players of the immune system: differences and interplay between innate and adaptive immunity, how immune cells develop and function, how immune cells recognize threats and danger and mount an appropriate and measured response. This course is offered in the Fall term with in-class lectures and tutorials, as well as in the Summer term with hybrid delivery (online lectures and in-class tutorials).
IMM340H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online hybrid course. Lectures are pre-recorded and posted every Tuesday at 9am. Tutorials are synchronous and are scheduled on Mondays at 3-4pm.

HIS342H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Political and Psychological Liberation in 20th Century Africa
HIS342H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course examines the growth of movements for the political liberation of Africa and the psychological liberation of Africans from Western imperialism and cultural hegemony. Postcolonial thinking and art was fundamental to the project of decolonization. It uses primary text and films to explore African cultural and intellectual history.

HMB342H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course engages students in the fundamental science of epidemiology applied to health and disease. After an introduction to various measures of health and disease, the scientific methods used to investigate, analyze, prevent and control health problems will be illustrated using social, biomedical and public health examples
HMB342H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures are delivered online at the scheduled class time. Tutorials will be mixed live tutorials, asynchronous work, and/or drop ins. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

PSY343H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Examines various theories of how personality functioning may become impaired and corresponding psychotherapeutic interventions. Emphasis on empirical assessment of personality dysfunction and therapy effectiveness.
PSY343H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Live virtual tutorial sessions (optional) will be offered at a few points throughout the semester.  Students will be able to participate in the discussion online (synchronously) or listen to a recording of the meeting (asynchronously).  All course assessments will be conducted online.

SOC345H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course examines the social processes that characterize stratification and social inequality across the globe, by looking at whether global inequality is growing, shrinking or stagnant and the impact of globalization on global inequality, with particular emphasis on examining disparities over time in education, income/wealth and health. This is a program-only course and is restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
SOC345H1-F-20215.prerequisite: SOC201H1, SOC202H1, SOC204H1 & 1.0 FCE from SOC251H1/SOC252H1/SOC254H1
SOC345H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Quercus,  Zoom, UofT email, and the Microsoft Office Suite
SOC345H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Quercus (Zoom); camera & microphone; PowerPoint.

Lectures and tutorials will be synchronous.

ANT346H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Social anthropological perspective on the nature and meaning of food production, culinary cultures, industrial food, food as metaphor, and famine and hunger.
ANT346H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be an online synchronous course, with lecture recordings available for asynchronous viewing.

CSB346H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course examines how the central and peripheral nervous system controls breathing in mammals. Topics include how the brain generates rhythmic breathing movements, how sleep impacts breathing control and how abnormal breathing contributes to disorders such as sleep apnea.
CSB346H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Delivery will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week. Students will have the opportunity for online class 1-2hrs/week (Monday and Wednesday 6-7pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra)

IRE347H1-F-20215.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE347H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The role of training and development initiatives in organizations. Students acquire the knowledge and skills to conduct a training needs assessment, identify training objectives, explore strategies to increase the transfer of training, design and deliver a training activity using various training methodologies, and evaluate its effectiveness.
IRE347H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in IRE courses cancelled at any time. For course details click on the course code in the timetable below and review the course description, prerequisites etc. before enrolling in a IRE course. Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about IRE courses.

ACT348H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Determination of benefit premium and benefit reserves for life insurance and annuities; analysis of insurance loss random variables; theory of life contingencies for multiple lives. Course manuals fee: $40.
ACT348H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ACT240H1 (minimum grade C); ACT245H1 (minimum grade C); ACT247H1 (minimum grade C); (STA257H1,STA261H1); MAT237Y1/MAT257Y1
ACT348H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online (per the meeting schedule) or pre-recorded. All livestreamed lectures will also be recorded for viewing.

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online lectures.

ANT348H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Medical Anthropology: Health, Power and Politics
ANT348H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course deepens students’ understandings of health and illness as social, cultural, political and historical phenomena. Drawing on theories and approaches from social-cultural anthropology, students will develop skills in critical analysis of experiences and meanings of healing and illness in particular contexts, with a focus on anthropological critique of dominant health policies, discourses, technologies and practices.
ANT348H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or permission of the instructor. (Note: ANT208H1 is not accepted preparation for this course.)
ANT348H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered via asynchronous videos posted online.

One two-hour live class session per week will include small group and whole-class discussion of readings and course material to support student comprehension, and updates and feedback on assignments from the teaching team.  It is recommended but not required that students complete readings and watch lecture videos prior to these live sessions. Participation in the live sessions is strongly recommended but optional. It will require a microphone and ideally a camera. Video recordings of whole class discussion will be posted for those unable to participate in live sessions.

ECO349H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
ECO349H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
ECO349H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: The course has asynchronous and synchronous elements. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

CRI350H1-F-20215.orgName: Criminology and Sociolegal Studies, Centre for (CRI)
CRI350H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to social science research methods used by criminologists and to the statistical analysis of criminological data. An understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of published criminological research is developed. Specific technical issues related to sampling, measurement, and data analysis are taught in the context of examining ways of answering research questions.
CRI350H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in those courses cancelled at any time. Contact the Program Office (CrimSL@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about CRI prerequisites/exclusions.
CRI350H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course will be online ASYNCHRONOUS delivery.

ECO351H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Courses may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the prerequisites announced by the Department.
ECO351H1-F-20215.prerequisite: See the Department of Economics website for details.
ECO351H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered as per course schedule. In special circumstances, recordings of lectures will also be made available for students to view asynchronously. Since participation during lectures is an important element of the course, It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

ECO358H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to economics of financial assets and financial markets. Topics: inter-temporal choice, expected utility theory, security valuation, selected asset pricing models, market efficiency, and the term structure of interest rates - essential materials for an understanding of the role and operation of financial markets.
ECO358H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
ECO358H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

JGJ360H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course examines literary works written in different languages, in ghettos and concentration camps during the Holocaust, as well as those reflecting on the genocide in its aftermath. We focus on literature as a means of engaging with the unimaginable and on the cross analysis of eye-witness and memory writing.
JGJ360H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Completion of a minimum of 4.0 FCEs
JGJ360H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, synchronous course. Students are expected to be logged into the course on Tuesdays from 10am-1pm EST and Thursdays 10am-12pm EST every week, when they will be virtually attending lectures, delivered in real time, and participating in online discussions, again, in real time. All readings and audio/visual materials will be posted on course website.

ARH361H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Opportunity for students participating in non-degree credit archaeological digs to submit reports, field notes and term papers for degree credit. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ARH361H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Permission of Undergraduate Co-ordinator and Supervisor
ARH361H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For information on how to enrol in this course, please contact Josie Alaimo, Undergraduate Administrator, at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca

POL363H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course introduces students to Canadian political development – an approach that shows how attention to history can illuminate and explain patterns of Canadian politics. The course introduces students to core theories and tools of a developmental approach, then applies this approach to key moments, contestations, and institutions in Canadian politics.
POL363H1-F-20215.exclusion: POL382H1 (Topics in Canadian Politics: Canadian Political Development), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019
POL363H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Online class discussions will be held during the scheduled meeting times to discuss topics in the lectures and to assist students with course material.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online discussions.

ECO364H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An examination of the causes and consequences of international trade. The first half develops traditional models of comparative advantage. The second half examines more recent theoretical and empirical work on trade & wages, the political economy of trade, outsourcing, and firm heterogeneity.
ECO364H1-F-20215.prerequisite: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
ECO364H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

ECO365H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to open economy macroeconomics and international finance. The core objective of the course is to develop macroeconomic models of open economies that can be applied towards gaining an understanding of recent events such as US deficits, financial crises, China's exchange rate policy and the Euro.
ECO365H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

WGS367H1-F-20215.courseTitle: The Politics of Gender and Health
WGS367H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Examines diverse traditions and normative models of health (e.g. biomedicine, social constructionist, indigenous health) in conjunction with analyses of the origin, politics, and theoretical perspectives of contemporary Womens Health Movements. Topics may include fertility, sexuality, poverty, violence, labour, ageing, (dis)ability, and health care provision.
WGS367H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

PHY372H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An individual study program chosen by the student with the advice of, and under the direction of, a staff member. A student may take advantage of this course either to specialize further in a field of interest or to explore interdisciplinary fields not available in the regular syllabus. Consult the department web site for some possible topics. This course may also be available in the summer. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PHY372H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Consult the Physics Associate Chair (Undergraduate Studies)
PHY372H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: All undergraduate inquiries, please contact: Undergraduate Coordinator at ugcoord@physics.utoronto.ca or 416-978-7057.

POL373H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Emotions are central to political life but have often been marginalized in political theory. This course explores various ways in which emotions are relevant to political theory and examines a number of contemporary debates around the new possibilities in bringing a positive consideration of the emotions back into political theory.
POL373H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures and discussion will be delivered online synchronously and recorded per the meeting schedule.
  • Participation is a key component of the course which will make consistent asynchronous access a hindrance to good performance in the course.

JLP374H1-F-20215.courseDescription: In Psychology of Language, we investigate human and other animal communication, structure of human language, word meaning and semantic memory, psychological studies of syntax, bilingualism, language and thought, language errors and disorders. (Sponsored by the Departments of Linguistics and Psychology, but administered solely by the Dept. of Linguistics).
JLP374H1-F-20215.prerequisite: One FCE from LIN228H1, LIN229H1, LIN232H1, LIN241H1, PSY260H1, PSY270H1, PSY280H1, PSY290H1, COG250Y1
JLP374H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and also recorded. Lecture recordings will be posted on Quercus and students will have the opportunity to review the recordings. Students need the ability to use Zoom and will be expected to be able to participate orally or through the chat. Students may also be expected to watch videos before class meetings. Students will also be expected to engage with course content on the Quercus discussion board.

PHL375H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An intermediate-level study of selected issues in moral philosophy, or of influential contemporary or historical works in ethical theory.
PHL375H1-F-20215.prerequisite: PHL275H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy
PHL375H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be livestreamed via Zoom as per the schedule and recordings will be available for asynchronous viewing. Students will require a microphone in order to participate in discussions.

POL377H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the field of comparative politics. Content in any given year depends on instructor.
POL377H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be held synchronously and recorded to watch asynchronously.
  • Students will be expected to watch films prior to class meetings.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to
    participate in online activities.

PSL378H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity to go outside of the traditional university classroom and actively participate in a marine mammal autopsy. Learn the diversity and adaptive nature of marine mammalian physiology/anatomy as it compares to human. The course is 2 weeks (in May), one week of hands-on tissue dissection, and one week of group discussions of the findings and draft report preparation. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PSL378H1-F-20215.prerequisite: BIO270H1, BIO271H1/PSL201Y1/PSL280H1/PSL300H1, PSL301H1 or permission of the course coordinator
PSL378H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
For PSL378H1, 'E' indicator: this is a two weeks intensive summer field course from May 17 - 28, 2021. Week one will be in-person and virtual dissection at the University of Toronto, week two will be done virtually.   
Additional information and application may be obtained in http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl378h1f. 
Space is limited and requires course director approval no later than April 1, 2021. Please note that there is a course fee in addition to the university registration.
PSL378H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Week one will be in-person and virtual dissection at the University of Toronto, week two will be delivered online synchronously.   
Additional information and application may be obtained in http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl378h1f. 
Space is limited and requires course director approval no later than April 1, 2021. Please note that there is a course fee in addition to the university registration.

PSL379H0-F-20215.courseTitle: Comparative Marine Mammal Physiology in the Field
PSL379H0-F-20215.courseDescription: Hands-on monitoring of physiological measures with live dolphins, manatee and sea lions; field observations and applied learning to a physiology project. Two-weeks at the end of April early May: 1st week at marine research center in Mexico, 2nd week of wrap-up discussion and integration of data at U of T. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PSL379H0-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For PSL379H0/1, 'E' indicator: Additional information is available at http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl379h.  Please note that spaces are limited and is allocated on a first come first served basis.
PSL379H0-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
The Department of Physiology will be offering a two weeks virtual ‘up close and personal videos’ with various species of dolphins & seals.  The first week is spend on BBcollaborate virtually visiting our marine mammals and the second week will be virtual daily class meetings to discuss individual projects, group discussion of the information learned and applied.

On-line Course Date: April 26 - May 7, 2021

PSL379H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For PSL379H0/1, 'E' indicator: Additional information is available at http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl379h.  Please note that spaces are limited and is allocated on a first come first served basis.

On-line Course Date: April 26 - May 7, 2021

CIN380H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Special Topics in History and Nation
CIN380H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies.
CIN380H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be online synchronous and followed by class discussion in seminar format. While lectures will be recorded, synchronous attendance and participation are mandatory. Screenings will be asynchronous and accessible through Quercus. Students will need a steady internet connection, a functional webcam, and microphone to access screenings as well as Zoom and PowerPoint, which are downloadable applications through the University of Toronto.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Clash on Screen: Multiculturalism in Recent European Cinema

FAH380H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The study of various aesthetic, cultural, social, political, and theoretical aspects of Western art and photography across the centuries.
FAH380H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Two FAH half courses or permission of instructor
FAH380H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of the lectures will also be made available for students to view asynchronously.

SMC380H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC380H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least ten full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval; at least one month before the beginning of the semester.
SMC380H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For "E" indicator courses, please contact the SMC Program Administrator at smc.programs@utoronto.ca.

ENG385H1-F-20215.courseDescription: This course explores English from its prehistory to the present day, emphasizing Old, Middle, and Early Modern English and the theory and terminology needed to understand their lexical, grammatical, and phonological structure; language variation and change; codification and standardization; literary and non-literary usage.

HIS385H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A study of political, economic, and social change in the British colony of Hong Kong from 1842 until the present day.
HIS385H1-F-20215.exclusion: Students cannot take both the Y and H version of HIS385

SMC386H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Credit is offered to a student doing an internship with a media organization formally recognized as a partner of St. Michael's College and the Book and Media Studies Program. SOC386H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity to explore new topics in sociology. Topics vary from year to year based on the instructor. Consult the Departmental website: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/new-topics-in-sociology/

PHL388H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The literary expression of philosophical ideas and the interplay between literature and philosophy. Such philosophical issues as the nature and origin of good and evil in human beings, the nature and extent of human freedom and responsibility, and the diverse forms of linguistic expression. Such authors as Wordsworth, Mill, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Miller, Camus, and Lawrence are studied.
PHL388H1-F-20215.prerequisite: 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy
PHL388H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be live-streamed at the scheduled meeting times via BB Collaborate. Lectures will also be recorded for asynchronous viewing. A camera and microphone is recommended for those who wish to participate during synchronous lectures.

HIS389H1-F-20215.courseDescription: In-depth examination of historical issues. Content in any given year depends on instructor. See History website for more details.
HIS389H1-F-20215.prerequisite: 9.0 FCEs including 1.0 FCE HIS course. Further pre-requisites vary from year to year, consult the department.

DTS390H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A scholarly project chosen by the student, approved by the Department, and supervised by one of its instructors. Consult with the Diaspora and Transnational Studies Program Office for more information. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

GER391H1-F-20215.courseTitle: iPRAKTIKUM Experiential Learning and Internationalization Internship
GER391H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The course provides curricular support for a variety of work and community-engaged, experiential learning placements in the GTA and in German-speaking countries. The placements are designed to deepen linguistic, cultural, and analytical skills acquired in the classroom in work-related environments, create an awareness of the translatability of academic knowledge to other contexts, promote global competency, and foster links to the community. The number of weekly hours spent in the field, the scope of learning objectives, and the nature of reflective activities are determined on an individual basis in consultation with the host institution, the German Department, and other units in which the student is pursuing a program degree (as required). In addition to successfully achieving the formulated learning goals, students must complete assignments such as eJournals and research papers as well as participate in peer-to-peer reporting and post-placement interviews.
GER391H1-F-20215.prerequisite: GER100Y1 and GER200Y1 or consent of department (equivalent proficiency level B1)

NEW391H1-F-20215.courseDescription: New College Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
NEW391H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Minimum of 8.0 FCEs completed and permission of College
NEW391H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Enrolment is by application. For more information and application forms, please see the Independent Studies website: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/independent-studies/
NEW391H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent studies courses is unique to each project. The projects must be fully online, and may have a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components. Weekly contact hours for this course will vary depending on the project and will be determined in consultation with the research supervisor.

SOC391H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Independent Research courses allow students to pursue a specific topic of interest. These courses are offered at the 300-level, as full or half courses. Students work independently with a professor in the Department who acts as research supervisor. There are no formal class meetings, lectures, or readings other than what is agreed to with the supervisor. Professors accept supervisory responsibility at their discretion. They are not required to serve as research supervisors. It is recommended that students approach a professor working in the same sub-discipline of sociology. Often students become interested in a topic through a SOC course and approach the instructor of that course for supervision; however, this is not required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For further details, please visit our website at: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/independent-research-course/
SOC391H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Students must have completed 10.0 courses towards their degree, plus a SOC course at the 300+ level to be eligible for 300-level Independent Research.
SOC391H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: students must contact the Undergraduate Program Administrator at sociology.undergraduate@utoronto.ca

RSM392H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Introduces core ideas, concepts and models in the area of Strategic Management. Addresses the following questions: Why does firm performance vary across industries, and across firms within a given industry? What types of competitive strategies can managers pursue? When are different types of strategies more or less likely to be successful? Enrolment is restricted to 3rd or 4th year Rotman Commerce students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM392H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

RLG393H1-F-20215.courseTitle: Graphic Religion: Myth and the Spiritual in Graphic Novels
RLG393H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Survey of themes connecting religious ideas, symbols, and representations with graphic novels and sequential art. The course will explore techniques of story-telling in mythic and visual representations in religious traditions and explore how these techniques and images are mirrored within popular comic-style (sequential) art.
RLG393H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous course. Some or all lectures and class meetings will be livestreamed to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously, which registered students can access on their own time. Students will have the opportunity for weekly online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content and assignments. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources and Quercus tools, including Bb Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

MAT395H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Independent reading under the direction of a faculty member. Topic must be outside current undergraduate offerings. Similar workload to a 36L course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

EAS396H1-F-20215.courseDescription: A study of Chinese, Japanese or Korean culture, history and/or literature. Content depends on the instructor. When offered, the course will have a subtitle that describes its content.
EAS396H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students are expected to participate synchronously at the scheduled times. Students who cannot attend synchronously for a reason such as time zone difference may request that recorded material be made available to them.

PSY396H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The functional relevance of neurotransmitters, with particular emphasis on their role in mediating behaviour.
PSY396H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: All lectures and assessments will be available online. Recordings of synchronous sections will be available for students to view asynchronously.

PSY397H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Daily, monthly, annual and other rhythms and methods of measuring them. Behavioural and physiological aspects of biological clocks. The importance of rhythms in experimental design, in research on brain function, in affective disorders, and the use animals make of rhythms in migration and other behaviours.
PSY397H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be live-streamed to allow for synchronous (real time) online viewing. Lectures also will be recorded (possibly audio only) to allow for asynchronous viewing or review. All course assessments will be conducted online. Tests will be held during the regular class time according to the syllabus and will be followed by a lecture.

WGS397H1-F-20215.courseDescription: The course communicates the growing field of "girl studies" and provides a critical exploration of the historical, social, psychological and political definitions attached to girlhood. We will move toward a feminist understanding of how definitions of girl-child shape individual experience, historical narratives, cultural representations, political agendas and futures.
WGS397H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

CLA398H0-F-20215.courseDescription: An instructor-supervised group project in an off-campus setting. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rep. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CLA398H0-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop
