PSY424H1-S-20215.courseDescription: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.

IRE431H1-S-20215.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE431H1-S-20215.courseTitle: Canadian Labour Law & the Unionized Workplace
IRE431H1-S-20215.courseDescription: The course will focus on the laws impacting unionized workplaces. It will cover every phase of the Ontario Labour Relations Act, 1995 (the “LRA”) from union organizing, certification, negotiation and bargaining, collective agreement arbitration, retention of bargaining rights and decertification and termination of bargaining rights.
IRE431H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in IRE courses cancelled at any time. For course details click on the course code in the timetable below and review the course description, prerequisites etc. before enrolling in a IRE course. Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about IRE courses.

ANT441H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Beginning with anthropologys early work on kinship, and ending with recent analyses of sex work and the globalization of ideologies of romantic love and companionate marriage, this course will investigate how emotional and sexual relationships are produced, used, conceptualized, and experienced both within particular societies and transnationally.

ESS450H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A ten-day field course in late August at the Deep River field site. Students get hands-on experience using geophysical instrumentation, applying various data collection techniques, and performing data analysis in gravity, magnetic, seismic, electrical, electromagnetic, and radar surveys. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: Enrollment is handled by the department. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca. Additional fee of up to $500 will apply.

SMC457H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Based on a professor's research project currently in progress, this course will enable an undergraduate student to play a useful role in the project while receiving hands-on training in research. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC457H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

SDS458H1-S-20215.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS458H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A research essay under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity, the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SDS458H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Please contact Valley Weadick at sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca for further information.
SDS458H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: Delivery methods for independent study are unique to each project. Meetings may be synchronous or asynchronous depending on the needs of the faculty supervisor, student, and project.

PHY472H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An individual study program chosen by the student with the advice of, and under the direction of, a staff member. A student may take advantage of this course either to specialize further in a field of interest or to explore interdisciplinary fields not available in the regular syllabus. Consult the department web pages for some possible topics. This course may also be available in the summer. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PHY472H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Consult the Physics Associate Chair (Undergraduate Studies).
PHY472H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: All undergraduate inquiries contact: Undergraduate Coordinator at ugcoord@physics.utoronto.ca or 416-978-7057.

PHY478H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An individual experimental or theoretical research project undertaken with the advice of, and under the direction of, a staff member. A student may take advantage of this course either to specialize further in a field of interest or to explore independent research. Consult the department web site for some possible topics. This course may also be available in the summer. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PHY478H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Consult the Physics Associate Chair (Undergraduate Studies)
PHY478H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses and any undergraduate inquiries contact: Undergraduate Coordinator at ugcoord@physics.utoronto.ca or 416-978-7057.

SMC480H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC480H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least fifteen full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval at least one month before the beginning of the semester.
SMC480H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For "E" indicator courses, please contact the SMC Programs Administrator at smc.programs@utoronto.ca.
SMC480H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

FAH481H1-S-20215.courseDescription: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
FAH481H1-S-20215.prerequisite: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)
FAH481H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please contact contact Louise Kermode at the Art Department for details, email undergrad.arthistory@utoronto.ca.

ENG483H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Seminars are designed to provide students with the opportunity to practice their skills of research and interpretation, and to participate in critical discussion, at a particularly advanced level. All seminars demand substantial class participation and most require an oral presentation. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ENG483H1-S-20215.prerequisite: 4.0 ENG FCE (including ENG202H1, ENG203H1, ENG250H1, ENG252H1); and any 9.0 FCE

SOC483H1-S-20215.courseDescription: This course examines the social foundations of thinking and action, with a focus on how individuals think and act through shared cognitive schemas that are embedded in larger social structures. The course is organized around a wide-ranging array of classical and contemporary theories that help explain the various factors that shape culture and cognition. There is a research component to put this analytical understanding into practice. Restricted to 4th-year sociology majors and specialists.

POL486H1-S-20215.courseDescription: For advanced students of international relations. Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor.
POL486H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.
  • Students may watch/listen to lectures and other class material on their own schedule.

POL487H1-S-20215.courseDescription: For advanced students of international relations. Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor.
POL487H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Course will be offered Online-Synchronous.
  • It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera for participation in seminar discussions.
  • Students are expected to do readings, and watch video and audio content and online lectures before seminar; content will be available via Quercus.

CRI490H1-S-20215.orgName: Criminology and Sociolegal Studies, Centre for (CRI)
CRI490H1-S-20215.courseTitle: Advanced Topics in Criminology and Sociolegal Studies
CRI490H1-S-20215.courseDescription: The objective of the course is to explore emerging issues in Criminology, and their social, legal, ethical and political implications. Topics vary from year to year.
CRI490H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
Registration priority will be given to students in the Criminology and Sociolegal Program (St George Campus) who have completed at least CRI205H1, CRI210H1 and 0.5 300 level CRI course.
Non-program students (year 3) completing a Social Science program may request special permission to enrol in the course (pending space availability) by sending an email to CrimSL@utoronto.ca. Make sure to include your student number. 
Students who have completed SOC429H5 are not eligible to take this course.

GER490H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A reading & research project in Germanic literature and/or culture involving a substantive research component. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
GER490H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Advanced status: permission of the department. Note: permission needs to be obtained by May 1st for the Fall Term and by Nov. 1st for the Spring Term
GER490H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: The deadline for submitting a proposal is in March. In exceptional cases, and if you have already have talked to a faculty member who is willing to support your proposal, please contact gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca for more information.

RSM490H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Focuses on developing an understanding of the fundamentals of doing business in an international environment. Based on the application of management theory (trade theory, modes of entry, foreign direct investment, theory of the multinational) to the strategic management problems of organizing business in the international arena. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM490H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

NEW491H1-S-20215.courseDescription: New College Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
NEW491H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Minimum of 12.0 FCEs completed and permission of College
NEW491H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Enrolment is by application. For more information and application forms, please see the Independent Studies website: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/independent-studies/
NEW491H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent studies courses is unique to each project. The projects must be fully online, and may have a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components. Weekly contact hours for this course will vary depending on the project and will be determined in consultation with the research supervisor.

CIN492H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Independent research projects devised by students and supervised by Cinema Studies faculty. Open to advanced Specialist and Major students in the Program. Submit applications to the Undergraduate Program Office: Fall 2016 courses, June 1/ Winter 2017 courses, November 1/ Summer 2017 courses, April 1. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CIN492H1-S-20215.prerequisite: At least ten full-course equivalents, including CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, CIN301Y1/ permission of instructor
CIN492H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Please note: Students must complete CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, and CIN301Y1 before taking any fourth year Cinema Studies courses. For "E" indicator Cinema Studies Courses: Contact the Undergraduate Assistant, 416-978-8571, cinema.studies@utoronto.ca

RLG492H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Student-initiated intensive research courses supervised by faculty members of the Department. The student must obtain both a Supervisor's agreement and the Department's approval in order to register. The maximum number of Independent Research courses one may take is two full-course equivalents. Deadline for submitting applications to Department, including Supervisor's approval, is the first week of classes of the session. A full-course may be compressed into a single session or spread through two sessions; a half-course may similarly be done in either one session or across two sessions. These courses are open to majors and specialists only. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

SOC492H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Independent Research courses allow students to pursue a specific topic of interest. These courses are offered at the 400-level, as full or half courses. Students work independently with a professor in the Department who acts as research supervisor. There are no formal class meetings, lectures, or readings other than what is agreed to with the supervisor. Professors accept supervisory responsibility at their discretion. They are not required to serve as research supervisors. It is recommended that students approach a professor working in the same sub-discipline of sociology. Often students become interested in a topic through a SOC course and approach the instructor of that course for supervision; however, this is not required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For further details, please visit our website at: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/independent-research-course/
SOC492H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Students must have completed 15.0 courses towards their degree, plus a SOC course at the 300+ level to be eligible for 400-level Independent Research.
SOC492H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: students must contact the Undergraduate Program Administrator at sociology.undergraduate@utoronto.ca

ENV493H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A research project or selected topic in an area of environment not otherwise available in the Faculty, meant to develop skills in independent study of interdisciplinary topics. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a School of the Environment program. A written proposal co-signed by the student and supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Academic Associate Director of the School normally one month prior to commencing the course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ENV493H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Note: Students can download the application form and course outline by going to https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/
ENV493H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: This independent studies course will be delivered online asynchronously, with student arranging meeting times with their supervisor.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

PSY493H1-S-20215.courseDescription: This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face, remembering a birthday from childhood, understanding the words in a spoken lecture, or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research, to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.
PSY493H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during weekly scheduled meetings that will be available through an online platform. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and tests. All course assessments will be conducted online.

USA494H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
USA494H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For more information on how to enrol, please send an email to csus@utoronto.ca.

ITA495H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Based on a professor’s research project currently in progress, this course will enable an undergraduate student to play a useful role in the project while receiving concrete training in research. This course is mandatory for all students enrolled in the specialist’s program.
ITA495H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: contact the Undergraduate Coordinator at 416-978-6304 or italian.undergrad@utoronto.ca for an appointment.
ITA495H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: Timing of lectures and meetings to be determined by instructors. In-person meetings with instructor only if allowed. Students will need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate) and the ability to use MSTeams or Zoom for interactive sessions. Students are expected to have cameras on all the time.

PHL495H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Individual Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PHL495H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: students can download Independent Study forms off the Philosophy Department website: https://philosophy.utoronto.ca/st-george/undergraduate-at-st-george/courses/individual-studies-courses/. All forms must be received at Jackman Humanities Building, 170 St. George Street, Room 403 or by email to eric.correia@utoronto.ca, no later than the first week of classes.

POL495Y1-S-20215.courseDescription: Open only when a Political Science full-time faculty member is willing and available to supervise. Students must find an appropriate supervisor in the Department of Political Science and obtain the approval of the Director of Undergraduate Studies before enrolling. Obtain details and an application form from the Department Undergraduate Office. Application forms can also be downloaded from the Department's website at www.politics.utoronto.ca. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
POL495Y1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For POL 495Y/496H/497H Independent Study courses: Instructions and application forms are available on the Departments website http://politics.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/student-forms/.

SOC495H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity to explore new topics in sociology. Topics vary from year to year based on the instructor. Restricted to 4th-year sociology majors and specialists. Consult the Departmental website: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/new-topics-in-sociology/

INS496H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Supervised independent research on a topic agreed on by the student and the supervisor before enrolment in the course. Available only when someone is willing and able to supervise. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
INS496H1-S-20215.prerequisite: INS201Y1 plus one additional INS designator full-course equivalent

MAT496H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Independent study under the direction of a faculty member. Topic must be outside undergraduate offerings. Workload equivalent to a 36L course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
MAT496H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Minimum GPA of 3.5 in APM and MAT courses. Permission of the Associate Chair for Undergraduate Studies and of the prospective supervisor.
MAT496H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students who wish to register for "E" indicator reading courses in mathematics are required to:(1) Seek the approval of supervising professor and format details of the research project. (2) Complete an application form which include project details. (3) Email application form to the Department of Mathematics at uginfo@math.toronto.edu for approval by the Associate Chair, Undergraduate Studies. (4) Approved courses are added to ROSI within 7 working days after the delivery of the completed application form. Application Deadline: May 10, 2021

ANT497Y1-S-20215.courseDescription: Supervised independent research on a topic agreed on by the student and supervisor before enrolment in the course. Open in exceptional circumstances to advanced students with a strong background in Anthropology. Course Supervisor must be a member of the Anthropology faculty. Application for enrolment should be made to the Department in the preceding term. A maximum of one year of Independent Research courses is allowed per program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ANT497Y1-S-20215.prerequisite: A minimum of 10 credits, permission of Supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator.
ANT497Y1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Please contact Josie Alaimo at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca to obtain an application form. Completed forms must be returned by June 28, 2021.

CSB497H1-S-20215.courseTitle: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I
CSB497H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An original research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be mutually agreed upon by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. In the Fall or Winter sessions, a commitment of 8-10 hours per week is expected for research and related course activities. If spread over both the Fall and Winter sessions, a commitment of 4-5 hours per week is expected. In the Summer Session, the number of hours doubles per week (e.g., 16-20 for F or S, or 8-10 for Y) as the length of the term is halved compared to the Fall or Winter term. Many students spend more than this amount of time as they become immersed in their project. This course is normally open only to fourth year students with adequate background in Cell and Systems Biology. Course requirements include a final report, and either an oral presentation (Summer and Fall sessions) or a poster presentation (Winter session). Two workshops on scientific research are scheduled and highly recommended. Details for enrollment are available at the Undergraduate course section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $25). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CSB497H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students must submit a completed CSB497/498/499 contract to the CSB Undergraduate Office at janet.mannone@utoronto.ca by Friday, 30 April 2021, before being enrolled. Contracts are available on our website at https://csb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-studies/forms/. For more information please contact janet.mannone@utoronto.ca.
CSB497H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

EEB497H1-S-20215.courseTitle: Research Studies in Ecology & Evolutionary Biology
EEB497H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An independent studies half-course allowing students to produce a literature review, which is supervised by a faculty member in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Highly motivated fourth-year students will work closely with a supervisor and be required to write up the results of their research in a final research paper. Students should contact a potential supervisor well before classes begin in the fall, winter, or summer session. Information on how to apply for the course is available on the EEB website. Students cannot take more than two independent research courses of EEB 497H1, 498Y1, and 499Y1, and the second project must be with a different supervisor. Students who apply to EEB497H1 in the fall session can also apply to enrol concurrently in EEB488H1Y. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
EEB497H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Application instructions for registration are found at http://www.eeb.utoronto.ca/undergrad/research.htm For more information, please contact the Undergraduate Office at undergrad.eeb@utoronto.ca.
EEB497H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: Meeting times and format to be determined with the supervisor.

POL497H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Open only when a Political Science full-time faculty member is willing and available to supervise. Students must find an appropriate supervisor in the Department of Political Science and obtain the approval of the Director of Undergraduate Studies before enrolling. Obtain details and an application form from the Department Undergraduate Office. Application forms can also be downloaded from the Department's website at www.politics.utoronto.ca. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

LIN498H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A research or reading project in linguistics undertaken by the student under the supervision of a staff member. Open only when a faculty member is willing and available to supervise. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
LIN498H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For enrolment please contact the Undergraduate Coordinator at ugling@chass.utoronto.ca

ANT499H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Supervised independent research on a topic agreed on by the student and supervisor before enrolment in the course. Open in exceptional circumstances to advanced students with a strong background in Anthropology. Course Supervisor must be a member of the Anthropology faculty. Application for enrolment should be made to the Department in the preceding term. A maximum of one year of Independent Research courses is allowed per program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ANT499H1-S-20215.prerequisite: A minimum of 10 credits, permission of Supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator.
ANT499H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Please contact Josie Alaimo at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca to obtain an application form. Completed forms must be returned by June 28, 2021.

CJS499H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A scholarly project on an approved topic supervised by a faculty affiliated with the Centre for Jewish Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CJS499H1-S-20215.prerequisite: CJS200H1 and permission of the Centre
CJS499H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in an Independent Study course, please read through the information on the ATCJS website and then contact Natasha Richichi-Fried at cjs.events@utoronto.ca.

COG499H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Advanced Independent Study. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
COG499H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: An application and College approval are required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC165, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca. Application is available on the Cognitive Science website at: https://www.uc.utoronto.ca/cognitive-science

ANT100Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Society and culture from various anthropological perspectives: socio-cultural, evolutionary, archaeological, and linguistic.
ANT100Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given online, synchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week (Professor and 2 TAs) to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.
ANT100Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Living Things and Their Environment (4), Society and its Institutions (3)

GER100Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription:
This is the language course to take if you have had no previous experience of the German language. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar. This course can be counted towards all programs in German.

Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are REQUIRED to take a placement test offered at the department.
GER100Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: Senior high school German or equivalent. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are required to take a placement test offered at the department.
GER100Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: If you have ANY background in the German language, you are required to take a placement test. Please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca to book a placement test as soon as possible. The test is a written test and takes thirty minutes. It takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St./wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor.

ITA100Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the main elements of the Italian language. The development of speaking, reading, and writing skills. Introduction to Italian culture and texts.
ITA100Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: Grade 11 and/or 12 Italian (U or M level) or previous experience or instruction in Italian.
ITA100Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students will be asked to fill out a questionnaire in order to make sure that they are placed in the proper course for their knowledge of Italian.
ITA100Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This course features a shared, pre-recorded asynchronous component delivered online to all students in the course. This component will take on average about one hour for every class meeting. This section of the course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule, but students will have to complete it before the active learning sessions of the course (consisting of 2 hours of instruction), which are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. In summary, because this is a Y course, it consists of 2 asynchronous hours + 4 synchronous hours every week. Students need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate), the ability to use MS Teams and/or Zoom for interactive sessions, a webcam and a microphone. Students are expected to keep cameras on all the time.

PHL100Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the central branches of philosophy, such as logic, theory of knowledge, metaphysics, ethics, and political philosophy. Writings from the central figures in the history of Western and non-Western philosophy, as well as contemporary philosophers, may be considered.
PHL100Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: PHL101Y1, PHL201H1, PHLA10H3, PHLA11H3, PHL101H5, PHL102H5, PHL105Y5
PHL100Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

SPA100Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to the Spanish language for beginning students; overview of basic grammatical structures, development of vocabulary and oral and written expression. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SPA100Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: No previous knowledge of Spanish, or placement test results.
SPA100Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: SPA120Y1, SPA219Y1, SPA319Y1, SPA220Y1, SPA320Y1, SPA420H1
SPA100Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: All students registered for the lecture MUST enrol in a tutorial section.
SPA100Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students need a webcam and audio recording capabilities (e.g. computer with a microphone) to access Quercus and to undertake oral and listening assessments.

HIS102Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Interactions among peoples, empires, and cultures, with particular attention to the non-European world. Can we speak of “international relations” before the modern concept of nation-states was established? What forms did globalization take in the pre-modern era? Covering a broad chronological sweep from before the Silk Road to the present day, we will look at exchanges of goods and technologies; dissemination of ideas and religions; voyages of migration and exploration; and episodes of conquest and colonization.
HIS102Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: HIS100Y1, HIS101Y1, HIS103Y1, HIS106Y1, HIS107Y1, HIS108Y1, HIS109Y1, HIS110Y1, HISA04H3/HISA05H3
HIS102Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Course will be taught online with synchronous lectures and tutorials.
HIS102Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Society and its Institutions (3), Thought, Belief and Behaviour (2)

CIN105Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
CIN105Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and discussion are online synchronous. Screenings will be online asynchronous. Students need internet connection, access to a web camera, and microphone for participation in online discussions.

CSC108H1-Y-20215.courseDescription:
Programming in a language such as Python. Elementary data types, lists, maps. Program structure: control flow, functions, classes, objects, methods. Algorithms and problem solving. Searching, sorting, and complexity. Unit testing. No prior programming experience required.

NOTE: You may not take this course concurrently with CSC120H1/CSC148H1, but you may take CSC148H1 after CSC108H1.
CSC108H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times. Students will need to be able to use videoconferencing tools, watch videos hosted online,  install software on their own computer, and complete online assessments. Computers with limited capabilities, such as Chromebooks, or tablets like the iPad, are likely NOT sufficient.

EAS110Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course is designed to help students build communication skills in the Korean language. Through an integration of listening, speaking, reading and writing, it aims to provide a solid foundation in beginning-level Korean. This course assumes that students do not have any prior knowledge of Korean. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
EAS110Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students must fill out the Screening Form prior to enrolment: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/enrolment-instructions/korean . Failure to submit the form will result in removal from course. Students must also attend an interview as scheduled by the professor/program coordinator within the first of class. For more information, please contact eas.undergrad@utoronto.ca.
EAS110Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a computer with a microphone, speakers and a webcam in order to participate. Students will be expected to self-study the asynchronous lecture on Saturdays/Sundays and on Wednesdays. Synchronous attendance required at tutorials.

ENG110Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course explores the stories that are all around us and that shape our world: traditional literary narratives such as ballads, romances, and novels, and also non-literary forms of narrative, such as journalism, movies, myths, jokes, legal judgments, travel writing, histories, songs, diaries, biographies.

NML110Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course is designed for students with no prior knowledge of Arabic. It places equal emphasis on the development of all language skills: reading, writing, listening, and speaking. The learning philosophy underlying this approach is that proficiency in a foreign language is best achieved through consistent, deliberate, and systematic practice. From the outset, students are strongly encouraged to develop the habit of consistently practicing learned material.
NML110Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.
NML110Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled, synchronous meeting. Students need a computer with a microphone and a camera in order to participate in online activities.

EAS120Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course is for students with no or a very limited background in Japanese. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ for details. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
EAS120Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students must fill out the Screening Form prior to enrolment: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/enrolment-instructions/japanese . Failure to submit the form will result in removal from course. Students must also attend an interview as scheduled by the professor/program coordinator prior to the start date of the class. For more information, please contact eas.undergrad@utoronto.ca.
EAS120Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a computer with a microphone, speakers and a webcam in order to participate. Synchronous attendance required at lectures and tutorials.

FSL121Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Intended for students having some knowledge of French but wishing to increase their proficiency to that of normal University entrance. Offers training in written and spoken French; reinforcement of reading comprehension and aural abilities; and an introduction to French-Canadian and Québécois cultures.
FSL121Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: FSL102H1, or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.
FSL121Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
This is an 8-hour course (4-hr lecture, 4-hr tutorial). Students will be assigned a tutorial by the instructor at the beginning of classes. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

Please note that Tutorials are included in the scheduled course times.

MAT133Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Calculus and Linear Algebra for Commerce
MAT133Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription:
Mathematics of finance. Matrices and linear equations. Review of differential calculus; applications. Integration and fundamental theorem; applications. Introduction to partial differentiation; applications.

NOTE: please note Prerequisites listed below. Students without the proper prerequisites for MAT133Y1 may be deregistered from this course.

Note that MAT133Y is not a valid prerequisite for a number of more advanced quantitative courses. Students who are considering a quantitative non-Commerce PoSt, such as a math minor or a stats minor, may want to consider MAT135H and MAT136H, MAT137Y, or MAT157Y instead of MAT133Y. Specifically, a student who took MAT133Y may need to subsequently take MAT135H and MAT136H as "extra" or take MAT137Y or MAT157Y in order to proceed in non-Commerce PoSts.
MAT133Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: MAT135H1, MAT136H1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, MATA30H3, MATA31H3, MATA32H3, MATA33H3, MATA35H3, MATA36H3, MATA37H3,  MAT133Y5, MAT134Y5, MAT135Y5, MAT137Y5, MAT138Y5, MAT186H, MAT187H, MAT194H, MAT195H, MAT196H & MAT197H
MAT133Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT136H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This second part of the introductory Calculus sequence focuses on integral calculus beginning with the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, the connection between two seemingly unrelated problems: measuring changing quantities and finding areas of curved shapes. Students will develop a deep understanding of the integral, and use it to: unpack equations involving derivatives; to make sense of infinite sums; to write complicated functions as 'infinite polynomials'; and to compute areas, volumes, and totals in applied problems. This course will further develop students' abilities to translate between algebraic, graphical, numerical, and verbal descriptions of mathematics in a variety of applied contexts.
MAT136H1-Y-20215.exclusion: MAT133Y1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1,  MATA32H3, MATA33H3, MATA36H3, MATA37H3,  MAT133Y5, MAT134Y5, MAT135Y5, MAT137Y5, MAT138Y5, MAT186H, MAT187H, MAT194H, MAT195H, MAT196H &  MAT197H
MAT136H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT137Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A conceptual approach for students with a serious interest in mathematics. Attention is given to computational aspects as well as theoretical foundations and problem solving techniques. Review of Trigonometry. Limits and continuity, mean value theorem, inverse function theorem, differentiation, integration, fundamental theorem of calculus, elementary transcendental functions, Taylor's theorem, sequence and series, power series. Applications.
MAT137Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: MAT135H1, MAT136H1, MAT157Y1,  MATA35H3, MATA36H3, MATA37H3,  MAT135Y5, MAT137Y5, MAT138Y5, MAT187H, MAT194H, MAT195H, MAT196H &  MAT197H
MAT137Y1-Y-20215.recommendedPreparation: Students will receive credit for both MAT137Y1 and MAT138H1 if MAT138H1 is taken before or along with MAT157Y1.
MAT137Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

CSC148H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Abstract data types and data structures for implementing them. Linked data structures. Encapsulation and information-hiding. Object-oriented programming. Specifications. Analyzing the efficiency of programs. Recursion. This course assumes programming experience as provided by CSC108H1. Students who already have this background may consult the Computer Science Undergraduate Office for advice about skipping CSC108H1. Practical (P) sections consist of supervised work in the computing laboratory. These sections are offered when facilities are available, and attendance is required. NOTE: Students may go to their college to drop down from CSC148H1 to CSC108H1. See above for the drop down deadline.
CSC148H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times. Labs will be available only as online synchronous and at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in lecture and lab activities.

CSC165H1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Mathematical Expression and Reasoning for Computer Science
CSC165H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to abstraction and rigour. Informal introduction to logical notation and reasoning. Understanding, using and developing precise expressions of mathematical ideas, including definitions and theorems. Structuring proofs to improve presentation and comprehension. General problem-solving techniques. Running time analysis of iterative programs. Formal definition of Big-Oh. Diagonalization, the Halting Problem, and some reductions. Unified approaches to programming and theoretical problems.
CSC165H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times. To participate in online activities, students require access to a desktop or laptop computer with a microphone, optionally a webcam, and a reliable high-speed internet connection.

ECO200Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Theory of markets and prices. Determination of prices through the interaction of the basic economic units, the household as consumer and as supplier of inputs and the business firm as producer and as employer of inputs. The pricing system as the mechanism by which social decisions and allocation of goods are made in a market economy.
ECO200Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

GER200Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course continues the work done in GER100Y1 / GER101H1. It further expands on basic grammar and vocabulary, practice in comprehension, composition, and conversation.
GER200Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: GER100Y1/GER101H1 or German placement test, Senior high school German or equivalent
GER200Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Pre-Requirement: Successful completion of GER100Y1 or GER101H1 or their equivalents or permission by the department. Self-placement is not allowed. Please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca for more information.

PHL200Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Central texts of the pre-Socratics, Plato, Aristotle, and post-Aristotelian philosophy.
PHL200Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be live-streamed via Zoom and recorded for asynchronous viewing. Tutorials will be live-streamed via Zoom. A web camera and microphone are needed for tutorials.

POL200Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Political Theory: Visions of the Just/Good Society
POL200Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A selective presentation of critical encounters between philosophy and politics, dedicated to the quest for articulation and founding of the just/good society. Among the theorists examined are Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes and Locke.
POL200Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be delivered online synchronous.
  • Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times.
  • Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings when indicated.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.
POL200Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Society and its Institutions (3), Thought, Belief and Behaviour (2)

INS201Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Indigenous Studies: Foundations, History and Politics
INS201Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the ideas, methods and themes of the discipline of Indigenous Studies. The development of the field of Indigenous Studies in Canada will form an important focus in the first half. The second part of the course will address "history and politics", including an overview of the historical processes of diplomacy, alliances, and treaty-making.
INS201Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Creative and Cultural Representations (1), Society and its Institutions (3)

ECO202Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Theory of output, employment and the price level; techniques for achieving economic stability; central banking and Canadian financial institutions and markets; foreign exchange markets and the exchange rate. This course is not intended for students enrolled in the BCom program; please see ECO209Y1.
ECO202Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used. 

  • Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).
  • Term tests and assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within 6 to 10-hour windows to accommodate different time zones. Some adjustments could be made in order to proctor the assessments.
  • There will also be online quizzes, generally between 2 to 3 hours per quiz, within three-day windows to complete.

ECO206Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO200Y1 and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
ECO206Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Lecture recordings and tutorial slides will be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

CSC207H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to software design and development concepts, methods, and tools using a statically-typed object-oriented programming language such as Java. Topics from: version control, unit testing, refactoring, object-oriented design and development, design patterns, advanced IDE usage, regular expressions, and reflection. Representation of floating-point numbers and introduction to numerical computation.
CSC207H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: 60% or higher in CSC148H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1  (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grade in CSC148H1 is lower than the minimum grade for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC148H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC148H1 before completing CSC207H1.)
CSC207H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times. Students need software development tools such as IntelliJ, Java, and Git.

enrollmentControls.postName: A&S Yr 1 Studies in Comp. Sci.
A&S Yr 1 Studies in Comp. Sci

ECO208Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO202Y1 and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
ECO208Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Recordings of lectures will be posted online for students to view asynchronously. However, tutorials, office hours, and assessments will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

CSC209H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Software techniques in a Unix-style environment, using scripting languages and a machine-oriented programming language (typically C). What goes on in the operating system when programs are executed. Core topics: creating and using software tools, pipes and filters, file processing, shell programming, processes, system calls, signals, basic network programming.
CSC209H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online, hybrid course with synchronous and asynchronous components. Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times.  Students will require internet access suitable for watching Youtube videos, participating in videoconferencing, and remote login. Students will need to be able to connect remotely to department servers to test and run their assignments.

SMC219Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.
SMC219Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Creative and Cultural Representations (1), Society and its Institutions (3)

ECO220Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics
ECO220Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Numerical and graphical data description; data collection and sampling; probability; sampling distributions; statistical inference; hypothesis testing and estimation; simple and multiple regression analysis (extensive coverage). Learn how to analyze data and how to correctly interpret and explain results. Use Excel to analyze a wide variety of data and replicate tables and figures in economics research papers.
ECO220Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: GGR270H1, PSY201H1, PSY202H1, SOC202H1, SOC252H1, STA220H1, STA221H1, STA248H1
ECO220Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students in LEC0201 must enroll in a tutorial (ie. TUT0101, TUT0201, TUT0301).
ECO220Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
LEC0101+0301: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. 

LEC0201: Lectures are offered online synchronously on Tuesdays, and online asynchronously on Thursdays. Students are strongly encouraged to attend the live synchronous elements, but recordings are provided for review. Students in LEC0201 must enroll in a tutorial (ie. TUT0101, TUT0201, TUT0301).
ECO220Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Society and its Institutions (3), The Physical and Mathematical Universes (5)

SPA220Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Intermediate Spanish for non-native speakers. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression.
SPA220Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students registered for the lecture MUST enrol for the corresponding tutorial.
SPA220Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students need a webcam and audio recording capabilities (e.g. computer with a microphone) to access Quercus and to undertake oral and listening assessments.

FSL221Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Intended for those who have some knowledge of French, this course is the first in a proficiency-sequenced series that provides students with the opportunity to become proficient, focused, autonomous French language learners. Adopting a principally actional approach to second language learning targeting Level A2 objectives of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR), the course’s main objective is to provide a communicative learning environment through activities based in real-world, everyday contexts.
FSL221Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: FSL121Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.
FSL221Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
This is an 8-hour course (4-hr lecture, 4-hr tutorial). Students will be assigned a tutorial by the instructor at the beginning of classes. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

Please note that Tutorials are included in the scheduled course times.

MAT223H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Systems of linear equations, matrix algebra, real vector spaces, subspaces, span, linear dependence and independence, bases, rank, inner products, orthogonality, orthogonal complements, Gram-Schmidt, linear transformations, determinants, Cramer's rule, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, eigenspaces, diagonalization.
MAT223H1-Y-20215.exclusion: MATA22H3, MATA23H3, MAT223H5, MAT224H1, MAT240H1, MAT240H5, MAT247H1, MAT247H5
MAT223H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT224H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Fields, complex numbers, vector spaces over a field, linear transformations, matrix of a linear transformation, kernel, range, dimension theorem, isomorphisms, change of basis, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalizability, real and complex inner products, spectral theorem, adjoint/self-adjoint/normal linear operators, triangular form, nilpotent mappings, Jordan canonical form.
MAT224H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
This is an online, hybrid course. 
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online live lectures each week. 
Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work. 
Please refer to our departmental website for more information on online teaching platforms: https://www.math.toronto.edu/cms/undergraduate-program/

MAT235Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Parametric equations and polar coordinates. Vectors, vector functions and space curves. Differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables. Line integrals and surface integrals and classic vector calculus theorems. Examples from life sciences and physical science applications.
MAT235Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: MAT237Y1, MAT257Y1, MATB41H3, MATB42H3, MAT232H5, MAT233H5, MAT236H5, MAT368H5, MAT291H & MAT294H
MAT235Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

CSC236H1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Introduction to the Theory of Computation
CSC236H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: The application of logic and proof techniques to Computer Science. Mathematical induction; correctness proofs for iterative and recursive algorithms; recurrence equations and their solutions; introduction to automata and formal languages. This course assumes university-level experience with proof techniques and algorithmic complexity as provided by CSC165H1. Very strong students who already have this experience (e.g. successful completion of MAT157Y1) may consult the undergraduate office about proceeding directly into CSC236H1 or CSC240H1.
CSC236H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: 60% or higher in CSC148H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1, 60% or higher in CSC165H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1 (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grade in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the minimum grade for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC165H1/CSC240H1 before completing CSC236H1. Students will not be permitted to retake CSC165H1 after completing CSC236H1.)
CSC236H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times. Tutorials will NOT be recorded and will be offered only online at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone (and, optionally, a camera) to participate in the online tutorial learning activities. Students need PDF viewer and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

enrollmentControls.postName: A&S Yr 1 Studies in Comp. Sci.
A&S Yr 1 Studies in Comp. Sci

MAT237Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Sequences and series. Uniform convergence. Convergence of integrals. Elements of topology in R^2 and R^3. Differential and integral calculus of vector valued functions of a vector variable, with emphasis on vectors in two and three dimensional euclidean space. Extremal problems, Lagrange multipliers, line and surface integrals, vector analysis, Stokes' theorem, Fourier series, calculus of variations.
MAT237Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: MAT235Y1, MAT257Y1, MATB41H3, MATB42H3, MATB43H3 & MAT368H5
MAT237Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT244H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: First order ordinary differential equations: Direction fields, integrating factors, separable equations, homogeneous equations, exact equations, autonomous equations, modeling. Existence and uniqueness theorem. Higher order equations: Constant coefficient equations, reduction of order, Wronskian, method of undetermined coefficients, variation of parameters. Solutions by series and integrals. First order linear systems, fundamental matrices. Non-linear equations, phase plane, stability. Applications in life and physical sciences and economics.
MAT244H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

PHL245H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to formal deductive logic. Semantics, symbolization, and techniques of natural deduction in sentential logic. Symbolization, natural deduction, and models in monadic predicate logic. Symbolization and natural deduction with polyadic predicates. Introduction to advanced concepts in first-order logic, such as operations, identity, and models.
PHL245H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

MAT246H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Designed to introduce students to mathematical proofs and abstract mathematical concepts. Topics may include modular arithmetic, sizes of infinite sets, and a proof that some angles cannot be trisected with straightedge and compass.
MAT246H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

CSC258H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Computer structures, machine languages, instruction execution, addressing techniques, and digital representation of data. Computer system organization, memory storage devices, and microprogramming. Block diagram circuit realizations of memory, control and arithmetic functions. There are a number of laboratory periods in which students conduct experiments with digital logic circuits.
CSC258H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: 60% or higher in CSC111H1/CSC148H1, 60% or higher in CSC111H1/CSC165H1/CSC240H1 (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grades in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/CSC240H1 are lower than the minimum grades for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC148H1 or CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/​CSC240H1 before completing CSC258H1.)
CSC258H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and labs will be delivered online at the scheduled times. The Monday timeslot is reserved for lab time. Students need a computer with a microphone in order to participate in online lab demos activities.

GER260Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course introduces Yiddish language, literature, music, theater, and cinema through interactive multi-media seminars, designed to build proficiency in reading, writing and comprehending. No prior knowledge of Yiddish is required.

CSC263H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Algorithm analysis: worst-case, average-case, and amortized complexity. Expected worst-case complexity, randomized quicksort and selection. Standard abstract data types, such as graphs, dictionaries, priority queues, and disjoint sets. A variety of data structures for implementing these abstract data types, such as balanced search trees, hashing, heaps, and disjoint forests. Design and comparison of data structures. Introduction to lower bounds.
CSC263H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: CSC236H1/ ​CSC240H1/ APS105H1/ APS106H1/ ESC180H1; STA237H1/ STA247H1/ ​STA255H1/ ​STA257H1/ ECE302H1/ STA286H1/ CHE223H1/ CME263H1/ MIE231H1/ MIE236H1/ MSE238H1/ ECE286H1
CSC263H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online at the scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in lecture and tutorial activities.

WGS271Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A critical examination of institutions, representations and practices associated with contemporary popular culture, mass-produced, local and alternative.
WGS271Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

NEW280Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Introduction to grammar and basic vocabulary of Swahili. Emphasis on comprehension and oral practice. Reading of selected texts. Relation of the language to its East African cultural context.
NEW280Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures are delivered online. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a course meeting time. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam, headset and microphone.

MAT295H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Independent study under the direction of a faculty member. Topic must be outside undergraduate offerings. Similar workload to a 36L course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
MAT295H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Minimum GPA of 3.5 in APM and MAT courses. Permission of the Associate Chair for Undergraduate Studies and of the prospective supervisor.
MAT295H1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students who wish to register for "E" indicator reading courses in mathematics are required to:(1) Seek the approval of supervising professor and format details of the research project. (2) Complete an application form which include project details.
