ANA300Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Structure of the human body and its relationship to function. Basic Human Histology, Gross Anatomy, and Neuroanatomy. Some content is delivered using online modules.
ANA300Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
There are eight hours of e-modules/lectures each week. 

In addition, each week there will be two, one-hour tutorials. Students must enrol in a tutorial to attend synchronously.
ANA300Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Course content will be taught using a mixture of e-modules and either synchronous or asynchronous lectures. Synchronous lectures will be recorded for asynchronous attendance. When content is delivered asynchronously, either via an e-module or recorded lecture, students will be given the opportunity to ask questions of the Course Director during a corresponding synchronous session during the scheduled class time. Weekly synchronous tutorials will emphasize practical anatomy and will not be recorded; students must attend their online tutorial at their scheduled time. Students must have access to a stable internet connection.

MAT301H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Congruences and fields. Permutations and permutation groups. Linear groups. Abstract groups, homomorphisms, subgroups. Symmetry groups of regular polygons and Platonic solids, wallpaper groups. Group actions, class formula. Cosets, Lagrange theorem. Normal subgroups, quotient groups. Classification of finitely generated abelian groups. Emphasis on examples and calculations.
MAT301H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: MAT224H1/MAT247H1, MAT235Y1/MAT237Y1, MAT246H1/CSC236H1/CSC240H1. (These Prerequisites will be waived for students who have MAT257Y1.) For FASE students, MAT185H, MAT194H, MAT195H.
MAT301H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

POL301Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: The continuing relevance of pre-colonial Africa; the nature and legacy of colonial rule; African nationalism and the consolidation of power in the newly-independent states; government, party and the people; the role of the military; national integration; dependency and neo-colonialism; socialism and development; democracy and human rights.
POL301Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate.

MAT315H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Elementary topics in number theory: arithmetic functions; polynomials over the residue classes modulo m, characters on the residue classes modulo m; quadratic reciprocity law, representation of numbers as sums of squares.
MAT315H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

RSM319H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Topics and Issues in Management. Content in any given year will depend on the instructor. Consult the Rotman Commerce Portal for course description and prerequisites. Enrolment is restricted to 3rd and 4th year Rotman Commerce students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
RSM319H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
Online – Asynchronous

Lectures will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

POL320Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: The development of political thought from the Enlightenment and through the 19th century; implications for political thought in the 20th century. Democratic and anti-democratic tendencies.
POL320Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will also be available to watch asynchronously for up to 1 week after recording
  • Tutorial are synchronous only
  • Students must watch lectures before tutorials
  • Students must have a microphone in order to participate in online activities.
  • A camera is recommended, but not required.

SPA320Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Advanced Spanish for non-natives. Selective review of grammar with emphasis on the complex sentence; intensive practice in written and oral expression to improve proficiency.
SPA320Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or placement test.
SPA320Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students enrolled in the lecture MUST enrol in the corresponding tutorial.
SPA320Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students need a webcam and audio recording capabilities (e.g. computer with a microphone) to access Quercus and to undertake oral and listening assessments.

FSL321Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: The course is intended for students who have already mastered the basic competences in French language proficiency. The textbook used in this course will follow the B1 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR) in its active approach which puts emphasis on the student being at the centre of the learning process. Students will learn the following intermediate-level language skills: writing, speaking as well as understanding written and spoken French.
FSL321Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test
FSL321Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: FSL375Y1 and higher. May not be taken concurrently with any FSL31*H1 series courses.
FSL321Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
This is an 6-hour course (4-hr lecture, 2-hr tutorial). Students will be assigned a tutorial by the instructor at the beginning of classes. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

Please note that Tutorials are included in the scheduled course times.

MAT327H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Metric spaces, topological spaces and continuous mappings; separation, compactness, connectedness. Fundamental group and covering spaces. Brouwer fixed-point theorem. Students in the math specialist program wishing to take additional topology courses are advised to obtain permission to take MAT1300H, MAT1301H.
MAT327H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: MAT157Y1/MAT157Y5/(MAT237Y1/(MATB41H3, MATB42H3, MATB43H3)/MAT237Y5, MAT246H1 and permission of the instructor)
MAT327H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

BCB330Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Special Project in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
BCB330Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity for specialized individual research in bioinformatics and computational biology by arrangement with the course coordinator and a supervisor. Significant background in both life science and computer science courses is required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
BCB330Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For more information about these courses, please visit: https://bcb.csb.utoronto.ca/. To enrol in these courses, please send an email with your student ID along with the completed registration form (available on the BCB website) to m.casco@utoronto.ca.
BCB330Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors. Students will work primarily on their own, but are required to meet with their supervisors at mutually convenient times throughout the term. In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

MAT334H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Theory of functions of one complex variable, analytic and meromorphic functions. Cauchy's theorem, residue calculus, conformal mappings, introduction to analytic continuation and harmonic functions.
MAT334H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

MAT337H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Construction of Real Numbers. Metric spaces; compactness and connectedness. Sequences and series of functions, power series; modes of convergence. Interchange of limiting processes; differentiation of integrals. Function spaces; Weierstrass approximation; Fourier series. Contraction mappings; existence and uniqueness of solutions of ordinary differential equations. Countability; Cantor set; Hausdorff dimension.
MAT337H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: MAT224H1/MATB24H3/MAT224H5/MAT247H1/MAT247H5, MAT235Y1/MAT235Y5/(MATB41H3, MATB42H3)/MAT237Y1/(MATB41H3, MATB42H3, MATB43H3)/MAT237Y5, MAT246H1; NOTE: These Prerequisites will be waived for students who have MAT257Y1
MAT337H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

POL340Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: International law as an instrument of conflict resolution. Recognition, sovereign immunity, subjects of international law, jurisdiction.
POL340Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Lectures will be delivered asynchronously.
  • Instructor will hold regularly scheduled (but optional) meet-ups where students can ask questions, and course material will be related to real-world events.
  • Students are expected to do readings, and watch video and audio content and online lectures before meet-ups.

MAT344H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Basic counting principles, generating functions, permutations with restrictions. Fundamentals of graph theory with algorithms; applications (including network flows). Combinatorial structures including block designs and finite geometries.
MAT344H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

APM346H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Sturm-Liouville problems, Green's functions, special functions (Bessel, Legendre), partial differential equations of second order, separation of variables, integral equations, Fourier transform, stationary phase method.
APM346H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

ENG364Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course explores twentieth-century American writing in a variety of genres.

MAT367H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Manifolds, partitions of unity, submersions and immersions, vector fields, vector bundles, tangent and cotangent bundles, foliations and Frobenius’ theorem, multillinear algebra, differential forms, Stokes’ theorem, Poincare-Hopf theorem
MAT367H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

CSC369H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Principles of operating systems. The operating system as a control program and as a resource allocator. The concept of a process and concurrency problems: synchronization, mutual exclusion, deadlock. Additional topics include memory management, file systems, process scheduling, threads, and protection.
CSC369H1-Y-20215.exclusion: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at FAS, UTM, or UTSC, or the Data Science Specialist at FAS, are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.
CSC369H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online at the scheduled times.

BCH372Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Real-world opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge and hone technical skills through full-time research in an active research laboratory for students who have completed second year. Students are responsible for arranging for supervision by a Department of Biochemistry faculty member in advance of the academic year-end. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
BCH372Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: A final grade of 75% or higher in BCH242Y1 and approval of the course coordinator.
BCH372Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please send an email, with your student #, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca
BCH372Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: In-person labs will be held if possible following institutional and public health guidance for physical distancing.

CSC373H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Standard algorithm design techniques: divide-and-conquer, greedy strategies, dynamic programming, linear programming, randomization, network flows, approximation algorithms. Brief introduction to NP-completeness: polynomial time reductions, examples of various NP-complete problems, self-reducibility. Additional topics may include approximation and randomized algorithms. Students will be expected to show good design principles and adequate skills at reasoning about the correctness and complexity of algorithms.
CSC373H1-Y-20215.exclusion: CSC375H1. NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at FAS, UTM, or UTSC, or the Data Science Specialist at FAS, are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.
CSC373H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online at the scheduled times.

SMC381Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC381Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least ten full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval; at least one month before the beginning of the semester.
SMC381Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For "E" indicator courses, please contact the SMC Program Administrator at smc.programs@utoronto.ca.
SMC381Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

CSC384H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Theories and algorithms that capture (or approximate) some of the core elements of computational intelligence. Topics include: search; logical representations and reasoning, classical automated planning, representing and reasoning with uncertainty, learning, decision making (planning) under uncertainty. Assignments provide practical experience, in both theory and programming, of the core topics.
CSC384H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: (CSC263H1/​ CSC265H1/ ECE345H1/ ECE358H1/ MIE335H1, STA237H1/ STA247H1/​ STA255H1/​ STA257H1/ STA237H1/ ECE302H1/ STA286H1/ CHE223H1/ CME263H1/ MIE231H1/ MIE236H1/ MSE238H1/ ECE286H1)/ Permission of the Cognitive Science Director
CSC384H1-Y-20215.exclusion: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at FAS, UTM, or UTSC, or the Data Science Specialist at FAS, are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.
CSC384H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online at the scheduled times.

DTS390Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A scholarly project chosen by the student, approved by the Department, and supervised by one of its instructors. Consult with the Diaspora and Transnational Studies Program Office for more information. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
DTS390Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: A scholarly project chosen by the student, approved by the Department, and supervised by one of its instructors. Consult with the Diaspora and Transnational Studies Program Office for more information. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

NEW390Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: New College Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
NEW390Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Minimum of 8.0 FCEs completed and permission of College
NEW390Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Enrolment is by application. For more information and application forms, please see the Independent Studies website: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/independent-studies/
NEW390Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent studies courses is unique to each project. The projects must be fully online, and may have a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components. Weekly contact hours for this course will vary depending on the project and will be determined in consultation with the research supervisor.

SOC390Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Independent Research courses allow students to pursue a specific topic of interest. These courses are offered at the 300-level, as full or half courses. Students work independently with a professor in the Department who acts as research supervisor. There are no formal class meetings, lectures, or readings other than what is agreed to with the supervisor. Professors accept supervisory responsibility at their discretion. They are not required to serve as research supervisors. It is recommended that students approach a professor working in the same sub-discipline of sociology. Often students become interested in a topic through a SOC course and approach the instructor of that course for supervision; however, this is not required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For further details, please visit our website at: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/independent-research-course/
SOC390Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Students must have completed 10.0 courses towards their degree, plus a SOC course at the 300+ level to be eligible for 300-level Independent Research.
SOC390Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: students must contact the Undergraduate Program Administrator at sociology.undergraduate@utoronto.ca

ACT391H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Internship course for students in the Actuarial Science Specialist, fulfilled as a 12-week work term in a workplace related to actuarial science in third or fourth year. ACT390H1 must be completed first in preparation. Contact Department for more information. (No tuition fee associated, however an ancillary fee of $720 will be assessed towards Professional Experience placement.)
ACT391H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This is the actuarial internship after the student has completed ACT390. Each student will have individual arrangement based on their internship employment contract and relevant university policies.

ESS392Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An individual study program chosen by the student with the advice, and under the supervision, of a faculty member. Such work may involve obtaining data in the field or lab and anlysing it, an interdisciplinary research project, and supervised readings. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ESS392Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: enrollment in an Earth Sciences Program of Study; completion of at least one full-course equivalent of 200-series ESS courses.
ESS392Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please contact Scott Moore, the Undergraduate Administrator, at s.moore@utoronto.ca.

HMB394Y0-Y-20215.courseDescription: Your individual, independent research project is supervised by a faculty member in an approved university. HMB394Y0-Y-20215.prerequisite: At least 8.5 FCEs including relevant courses in human biology.

CHM395Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An independent research project conducted under the direction of a teaching faculty or research faculty member in the Department of Chemistry. Applications for enrolment should be made to the Department before the end of the preceding Summer session. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CHM395Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Completion of at least 2.0 FCEs of CHM courses with a minimum cGPA of 3.0 in all CHM courses. Students are required to identify a potential faculty supervisor before contacting the Associate Chair, Undergraduate Studies for enrolment permission. Written confirmation is needed from both the Associate Chair, Undergraduate Studies and the prospective supervisor. Attendance at a mandatory safety orientation training session held during the first week of September.
CHM395Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please submit a request to the Chemistry Undergraduate Office at: chem.undergrad@utoronto.ca

CHM397H0-Y-20215.courseDescription: Independent research project in Chemistry under the supervision by a faculty member in an approved partner institution. This unique opportunity to conduct a lab-based research project is open to students in any Chemistry programs. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CHM397H0-Y-20215.prerequisite: Any CHM 300-level courses with lab; permission of the Department

CSB397Y0-Y-20215.courseTitle: Research Abroad in Cell & Systems Biology
CSB397Y0-Y-20215.courseDescription: An independent research project conducted in molecular biology, cell biology, developmental biology, neurobiology, physiology or systems biology. Whole organism, cell culture, in vitro or in silico studies are acceptable. The laboratory research is conducted by the student and supervised by a faculty member at an approved partner university. An information session is held each fall, and an application and interview process is required. The research is typically conducted from May to August. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CSB397Y0-Y-20215.prerequisite: Minimum grade of 73% in BIO230H1/BIO255H1/BIO271H1 and permission of the CSB397Y0 coordinator
CSB397Y0-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please contact the CSB Undergraduate Administrator.
CSB397Y0-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of these independent research projects will be done remotely in summer 2021.  There will be online synchronous and online asynchronous components.  Additional details will be provided by the supervisor at the host institution.

EEB397Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Research Project in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
EEB397Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An intermediate research project requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be one mutually agreed on by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. This course is open to highly self-motivated students who are in their Third Year and have a strong interest in ecology and/or evolutionary biology. Students are required to write up the results of their research in a formal paper, often in the format of a research article, and may be required to present the results at a poster session and/or participate in an oral presentation. Students should contact their potential supervisors over the summer before classes begin in September. Information regarding how to register for the course is available on the EEB website. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: cannot enrol if already taken the fourth year research project course EEB498Y1/EEB499Y1.
EEB397Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Application instructions for registration are found at http://www.eeb.utoronto.ca/undergrad/research.htm For more information, please contact the Undergraduate Office at undergrad.eeb@utoronto.ca.
EEB397Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Meeting times and format to be determined with the supervisor.

PCL397Y0-Y-20215.courseTitle: Research Abroad in Pharmacology and Toxicology
PCL397Y0-Y-20215.courseDescription: An independent research project in a pharmacology and/or toxicology laboratory in an approved partner university. This international research experience will be supervised by a faculty member at the partner institution and will allow students to develop critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PCL397Y0-Y-20215.prerequisite: PCL201H1 (65%), PSL300H1 (65%), PSL301H1 (65%); permission from the Undergraduate Coordinator
PCL397Y0-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students enroll in this course through the Department. Application through the Center for International Exchange (CIE) required. Please email undergrad.pharmtox@utoronto.ca.
PCL397Y0-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Health and safety guidelines and University travel policy will determine the status of this opportunity at the time of study.

MAT401H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Commutative rings; quotient rings. Construction of the rationals. Polynomial algebra. Fields and Galois theory: Field extensions, adjunction of roots of a polynomial. Constructibility, trisection of angles, construction of regular polygons. Galois groups of polynomials, in particular cubics, quartics. Insolvability of quintics by radicals.
MAT401H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

RSM403Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Open when a faculty member is willing and able to supervise. Students must obtain the approval of the Director of Rotman Commerce and the supervising faculty member before enrolling. Enrolment is restricted to 4th year Rotman Commerce students. Consult the Rotman Commerce Office for details. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.

RSM404Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Open when a faculty member is willing and able to supervise. TRN404Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Trinity Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

PSY405H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An intensive laboratory or applied research project under the supervision of a Department of Psychology faculty member. Project must be academically demanding and uniquely suitable for the individual student. Additional information and applications are available at the department and on its website. This course is open to all Psychology program students.
PSY405H1-Y-20215.prerequisite: PSY202H1 (or exclusion), and appropriate background for the proposed work
PSY405H1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For PSY405H1 and 406H1, 'E' indicator: Students must first obtain consent of an instructor in the Department to supervise their project.  Information and proposal form is available on our website.  The proposal signed by student and supervisor should be submitted to the Undergraduate Administrator for approval via email (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca).
PSY405H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Proposed research projects must be able to be completed remotely, should on-campus activities not be possible or public health guidelines dictate otherwise.  Contact hours will be determined by project supervisor.

POL417Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: The countries of Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East; their impact on the international system, and the external and internal factors that influence their international behaviour, with particular focus on civil wars.
POL417Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
• Seminar will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule.
  • Students are required to have a computer with a microphone and camera.
  • Camera is mandatory given that the seminar is based on the presentations and discussions.

FSL421Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An advanced course in French including the reading and discussion of texts focussing on the francophone presence and influence in the international context. Emphasis is placed on mastery of complex linguistic skills via use of a variety of reference tools and self-correction.
FSL421Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: FSL321Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.
FSL421Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

BCB430Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Advanced Special Project in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
BCB430Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity for advanced specialized individual research in bioinformatics and computational biology by arrangement with the course coordinator and a supervisor. Significant background in both life science and computer science courses is required. BCB330Y1 is a recommended preparation for this course however students should not normally conduct their project in the same laboratory or continue their previous project. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
BCB430Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For more information about these courses, please visit: https://bcb.csb.utoronto.ca/. To enrol in these courses, please send an email with your student ID along with the completed registration form (available on the BCB website) to m.casco@utoronto.ca.
BCB430Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors. Students will work primarily on their own, but are required to meet with their supervisors at mutually convenient times throughout the term. In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

HST451Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This two-semester course designation will permit students to gain academic credit for health studies pursued independently, or to participate in an ongoing health research project, under the supervision of a University of Toronto faculty member. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
HST451Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: An application and College approval are required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC165, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca. Application, guidelines, and supplementary documents are available on the Health Studies website at: https://www.uc.utoronto.ca/health-studies This course is open to Health Studies specialist and major students.

SDS459Y1-Y-20215.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS459Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A major research essay prepared over the course of two academic terms (one year); under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity; the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SDS459Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Please contact Valley Weadick at sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca for further information.
SDS459Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Delivery methods for independent study are unique to each project. Meetings may be synchronous or asynchronous depending on the needs of the faculty supervisor, student, and project.

APM462H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to first and second order conditions for finite and infinite dimensional optimization problems with mention of available software. Topics include Lagrange multipliers, Kuhn-Tucker conditions, convexity and calculus variations. Basic numerical search methods and software packages which implement them will be discussed.
APM462H1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Students must have a working microphone, access to a reliable internet connection, a webcam, and a camera or scanner that is able to upload clear images of student work.

BCH472Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Advanced Summer Research Project in Biochemistry
BCH472Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Real-world opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge and hone technical skills through full-time research in an active research laboratory for students who have completed third year. Students are responsible for arranging for supervision by a Department of Biochemistry faculty member in advance of the academic year-end. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
BCH472Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: A final grade of 75% or higher in each of BCH340H1; BCH377H1; BCH378H1; and approval of the course coordinator.
BCH472Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please send an email, with your student #, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca
BCH472Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: In-person labs will be held if possible following institutional and public health guidance for physical distancing.

PCL472Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course affords students an opportunity for hands-on research experience in a laboratory or applied pharmacology setting. Students will work under the supervision of a faculty member and will submit a final written report and oral presentation. Enrollment is limited and requires permission from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. It is the student’s responsibility to secure a placement with an approved supervisor before the course begins (a list of potential supervisors can be obtained from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology). Students will be registered in the course once their ballot form (obtained from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology) is signed by an approved supervisor and approved by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. Students are expected to spend approximately 200 hours towards this project but this will be project/supervisor dependent. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PCL472Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: PCL201H1, PCL302H1, PCL366H1/PCL367H1/PCL368H1, STA288H1/PCL376H1, and permission of Department
PCL472Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions:
This is a remote, hybrid course. The course will run primarily as asynchronous (i.e., students will work directly with their supervisor on project requirements), with some synchronous online meeting components to be determined at the outset of the course with the course coordinator. 


Students enroll in this course through the Department. Please email undergrad.pharmtox@utoronto.ca.
PCL472Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
LEC0101/LEC9101 - learning for this course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. There are no formal lecture meetings as part of this course. 

If Public Health and institutional guidelines allow, and by mutual agreement of the student and faculty supervisor, in-person meetings may be arranged.

PCL474Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course affords students an opportunity for hands-on research experience in a laboratory or applied toxicology setting. Students will work under the supervision of a staff member and will submit a final written report and oral presentation. Enrollment is limited and requires permission from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. It is the student’s responsibility to secure a placement with an approved supervisor before the course begins (a list of potential supervisors can be obtained from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology). Students will be registered in the course once their ballot form (obtained from the Department of Pharmacology) is signed by an approved supervisor and approved by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. Students are expected to spend approximately 200 hours towards this project but this will be project/supervisor dependent. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval at least one month before the beginning of the semester.

PHC489Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: This course will provide research experience under the supervision of a Departmental staff member. The goal is to deepen the student’s understanding of the scientific basis and practical techniques relevant to modern pharmaceutical development. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PHC489Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Permission from the Course Coordinator and enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.

NEW490Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent studies courses is unique to each project. The projects must be fully online, and may have a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components. Weekly contact hours for this course will vary depending on the project and will be determined in consultation with the research supervisor.

SOC490Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Independent Research courses allow students to pursue a specific topic of interest. These courses are offered at the 400-level, as full or half courses. Students work independently with a professor in the Department who acts as research supervisor. There are no formal class meetings, lectures, or readings other than what is agreed to with the supervisor. Professors accept supervisory responsibility at their discretion. They are not required to serve as research supervisors. It is recommended that students approach a professor working in the same sub-discipline of sociology. Often students become interested in a topic through a SOC course and approach the instructor of that course for supervision; however, this is not required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For further details, please visit our website at: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/independent-research-course/
SOC490Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Students must have completed 15.0 courses towards their degree, plus a SOC course at the 300+ level to be eligible for 400-level Independent Research.
SOC490Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For 'E' indicator courses: students must contact the Undergraduate Program Administrator at sociology.undergraduate@utoronto.ca

ENV491Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A research project or selected topic in an area of environment not otherwise available in the Faculty, meant to develop skills in independent study of interdisciplinary topics. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a School of the Environment program. A written proposal co-signed by the student and supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Academic Associate Director of the School normally one month prior to commencing the course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ENV491Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students can download the application form and course outline by going to https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/ and clicking on the "Syllabus" link for ENV492H or ENV493H. For more information, please contact David Powell at david.powell@utoronto.ca.
ENV491Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: This independent studies course will be delivered online asynchronously, with student arranging meeting times with their supervisor.

RLG492H1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Student-initiated intensive research courses supervised by faculty members of the Department. The student must obtain both a Supervisor's agreement and the Department's approval in order to register. The maximum number of Independent Research courses one may take is two full-course equivalents. Deadline for submitting applications to Department, including Supervisor's approval, is the first week of classes of the session. A full-course may be compressed into a single session or spread through two sessions; a half-course may similarly be done in either one session or across two sessions. These courses are open to majors and specialists only. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

NEW495Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: A placement-based course in which students develop knowledge, practice and professional skills appropriate to the social purpose sector while working to support programming for community partners. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

NEW495Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be available synchronously (live) at the scheduled course time and asynchronously (recorded). Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

HMB496Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription:
A research project course for students enrolled in a Human Biology program, supervised by a faculty member appointed in a faculty or division at St. George Campus (Faculties of Arts & Science, Medicine, Engineering, Dalla Lana School of Public Health, etc.). Open to third and fourth year students.


Students are responsible for securing their own supervisor. Should a HMB Specialist require help securing a supervisor, the request must be made by email to the Human Biology Program Office no later than July 20 for Academic year projects and January 30 for Summer projects.


Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website.


Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
HMB496Y1-Y-20215.prerequisite: Permission of the Human Biology Program; please refer to the Human Biology Program website for more details
HMB496Y1-Y-20215.exclusion: Students are not permitted to do a HMB research project concurrently with another research project
HMB496Y1-Y-20215.recommendedPreparation: 0.5 FCE or more in any statistics course
HMB496Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: To enrol in this course, please see current information on the HMB website here: https://www.hmb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/curriculum-course-info/research-projects-human-biology. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca
HMB496Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions:
The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components). In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives. Workshops are held over the F and S terms for students, and will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).

For students enrolled in the online-only HMB496/9Y1, if Public Health and institutional guidelines allow, and by mutual agreement of the student and faculty supervisor, in-person meetings may be arranged.

CSB498Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I
CSB498Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An original research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be mutually agreed upon by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. In the Fall/Winter session, a commitment of 8-10 hours per week is expected for research and related course activities. In the Summer session, the number of hours doubles (16-20 per week) as the length of the term is halved. This course is normally open only to fourth year students with adequate background in Cell and Systems Biology. Course requirements include a final report and either an oral presentation (Summer session) or a poster presentation (Fall/Winter session). Four workshops on scientific research are scheduled and highly recommended. Details for enrollment are available at the Undergraduate course section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $50). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CSB498Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Students must submit a completed CSB497/498/499 contract to the CSB Undergraduate Office at janet.mannone@utoronto.ca by Friday, 30 April 2021, before being enrolled. Contracts are available on our website at https://csb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-studies/forms/. For more information please contact janet.mannone@utoronto.ca.
CSB498Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

EEB498Y1-Y-20215.courseTitle: Advanced Research Project in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
EEB498Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: An advanced research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be one mutually agreed on by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. This course is normally open only to highly self-motivated students who are in their Fourth-Year and have adequate background in ecology and/or evolutionary biology. Students are required to write up the results of their research in a formal paper, often in the format of a research article, and are also required to present the results at a poster session and/or oral presentation. The time commitment is approximately 8 hours per week. Students should contact their potential supervisors over the summer before classes begin in September. Information regarding how to register for the course is available on the EEB website. Students in this course are also concurrently enrolled in EEB488H1Y Research Issues in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
EEB498Y1-Y-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Application instructions for registration are found at http://www.eeb.utoronto.ca/undergrad/research.htm For more information, please contact the Undergraduate Office at undergrad.eeb@utoronto.ca.
EEB498Y1-Y-20215.deliveryInstructions: Meeting times and format to be determined with the supervisor.

Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. Students who have completed both CSB497H1 and CSB498Y1 are excluded from taking CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $50).
